ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Susie Gharib, funded in part by --

(COMMERCIAL AD)

TYLER MATHISEN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Welcome to this special holiday of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I`m Tyler Mathisen. Susie Gharib has the night off.

Well, 2014 is almost in the books and it`s been filled with highs, many of them closing highs for the major indexes and lows like plummeting crude oil prices. But that wasn`t all that happened this year in the world of business. The economy and the job market hit a number of milestones as well. The health care sector dominated deal making, recalls roiled the auto business and a Chinese e-commerce company called Alibaba became the biggest IPO ever.

Tonight, we look back on 2014, the year that was.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): With the Dow notching record highs more than 30 times and the S&P about 50, the bull market is now more than 5 years old. But 2013`s perpetual push upward bumped into appear old acquaintance, volatility.

In November, stocks bounced up to new highs, but in December, there was another slide. Stock prices wavered just as the Federal Reserve prepared to end its economic stimulus program. Talk of the taper hung over the markets like a cloud a year ago. Now, it`s still about the Fed but the question is when it will begin to push interest rates back up?

Can the economy handle higher interest rates? Well, employment numbers are better but real incomes really aren`t and inflation is still below the Fed`s target level of 2 percent.

One reason for the low inflation: a historic drop in the price of oil, down more than 45 percent from the year`s high in June. Why? Well, it is simple and complex as the law of supply and demand. Supply is up. The U.S. alone has increased production 65 percent in just five years. Demand, though, is decidedly down, because the global economy is slowing.

Here at home, the drop in oil pushed gas prices down by a dollar a gallon and more in some places. Cheaper gas, of course, puts an estimated $100 billion back into the hands of U.S. consumers. That`s about 60 bucks a month for the typical household. But is that enough to get them spending again? Money still tight for most of us.

So, where is the U.S. finding growth? Companies are still sitting on record piles of cash. Some of that money is staying overseas as the wait for U.S. corporate tax reform lingers on.

But there`s plenty of money to invest in the latest technologies and corporate spending is helping to grow the economy. Tech is booming. Silicon Valley is a world leader. Apple`s new iPhones are a huge hit. In Seattle, Boeing (NYSE:BA) gets orders for more than fuel efficient jets from all over the globe and Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) expanded in New York City, which is suddenly flush with more than 4 million jobs, the most the Big Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) has ever had.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Quite a year. And we`ll start with Wall Street. The bull market, of course, proved it was alive and kicking. Major indexes closing at numerous records, almost too many to count, but it`s hard to talk about the stock market without touching on what may be the biggest story of the year for investors, oil prices.

So, with us, Dom Chu to focus on the stock market, Jackie DeAngelis on energy.

Welcome to you both. Happy holidays.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Happy holidays.

MATHISEN: Let me start with you, Dom. Sum it up in a few sentences for us.

DOMINIC CHU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you talk about the market, you cannot forget that we`ve hit record highs upon record highs, like you said.

So, as we look at what`s happening in 2014, this bull run is very much intact. But it was this time around, it wasn`t so much a lot of the technology names that we talked about before. It was health care that was a real driver for the market this time around. Those stocks, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals alike, a lot of deal-making like you said, all of that drove that to be the best performing sector in the S&P 500.

Of course, with those record highs, a lot of investors are calling to question whether or not they can sustain that going into 2015. Of course, the trend has been positive for a lot of them so far.

MATHISEN: You know, and when you look at those sectors, almost all of them higher except the one you follow most closely, which is energy. And were not for the falling oil prices, presumably, energy would be higher.

CHU: It`s been a huge drag, of course.

MATHISEN: Huge drag.

Lots of factors, we talked there in the piece about supply and demand. Is it really as simple as that?

DEANGELIS: It really is as simple as that. And, actually, I don`t think investors were expecting energy to be the story that it was in the back half of the year.

It certainly was no secret that supply was ramping the way analysts were expecting it to. As a matter of fact, this year, we finally started producing over 9 million barrels a day. That is almost up to the point of what Saudi Arabia`s output is. We never thought we`d be at that level.

At the same time, the demands part of the equation is what took us off guard. When the demand started to fall off, that`s prices started to decline. The question right now is, how do we curtail the supply to be able to meet the demand? Does the demand equation change in 2015 so that supply should stay stable right now? These are all the unknowns.

MATHISEN: Let`s talk a little bit about OPEC. Have they become irrelevant?

DEANGELIS: A lot of people are thinking the OPEC is becoming irrelevant but I would say the last meeting in November really changed the game. When they did not change their stance in terms of production and prices really tanked even further, OPEC was sort of showing some muscle and flexing it and saying, look, we`re in this game.

MATHISEN: So, what`s their end game? Is what they really to do, to squeeze out the higher cost U.S. producers or squeeze them so they scream?

DEANGELIS: I think what they`re worried about for themselves is losing shares. So, right now, they`re saying, we`re going to eat the price decline but we are going to hold on to market share. And if that squeezes shale, it squeezes shale. This is going to be a game of chicken, every man for itself, and it could get really ugly.

MATHISEN: Back to stocks. Falling oil prices really thought to be a net positive for the economy.

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: But in recent weeks, as oil has receded, collapsed in some people`s view --

CHU: Of course.

MATHISEN: -- equities hit a hard spot.

CHU: I mean, here, the numbers are quite staggering. Because just this quarter alone, the last quarter, and we`re only in the middle, we haven`t finished December at this point. By mid-December just in the S&P 500 energy companies alone, that oil price decline left the decline in stocks of all varieties in the energy sector. So much so that just this quarter to date, we`ve lost about $265 billion, with a B, dollars worth of market values for these energy companies.

So, this slide in oil price is huge. But it`s also important to remember that the driver for the economy right now, oil is a big part of it but it`s smaller part of the overall index than say, technology and financial stocks. Those two sectors are the most heavily weighted in the index. You want to see leadership there. If oil prices can rebound, that`s great as well.

MATHISEN: So, let`s spin in ahead here.

Why don`t you go first, Jackie? What is the outlook for energy prices over the first six months or all of 2015?

DEANGELIS: Well, for the first six months, certainly, analysts and traders alike are saying we could potentially go lower from here. Nobody really wants to call the bottom just yet until again, they get a sense of where this story is going, until some of the data shows us if the demand is going to come back on the table.

Having said that, people have also said to me, you know, once we do hit the bottom, maybe it`s somewhere in the 40s. We will rebound quickly back to the $60 or $70 range. So, that probably could happen in the back half of the year.

MATHISEN: And for you, Dom, we got back last week guidance from the Fed on interest rates.

CHU: We did.

MATHISEN: What`s the outlook for stock prices 2015?

CHU: Well, for 2015, what you`re seeing a lot of experts say is that you`re going to see the same level of valuation in the overall market, but it`s going to match earnings` growth. Earnings growth is not expected to be gang-busters but it`s still expected to grow. So, a lot of experts are seeing, yes, gains in the stock market. But you`re not talking about the 10 percent, 15 percent, 20 percent return varieties. You`re talking about --

MATHISEN: The profit growth and dividend.

CHU: -- maybe that 5 percent, 6 percent, 7 percent. Yes.

MATHISEN: Dom and Jackie, thanks very much. Appreciate it.

All righty. Now, to the economy, which is being helped by those low energy prices we just mentioned. But they didn`t start out that way. If anything, the brutal winners slammed the brakes on much of the country`s economic activity. But then the growth engine was turned on.

Steve Liesman reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Five long years after the end of the recession, a period marked by sluggish growth and stubbornly high unemployment, the U.S. economy may have turned a corner in 2014. Beginning the year with a surprise decline in growth, attributed to weather but causing many to say, here we go again. The U.S. economy proceeded to rocket ahead, tallying its best two quarters of growth since in 2003, and on track for its best year of job gains since 2000.

Unlike previous post-crisis growth spurts, this time it didn`t appear, the gains would be given back.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It`s pretty hard to find an economic measure where we`re not significantly better off. I don`t have to tell you about the stock market and where that`s gone, corporate profits, record highs. But also, unemployment now lower than it was previously. We`ve seen the housing market recover, although not as fast as we`d like, the auto industry recovering. We remain the most dynamic, innovative economy in the world.

LIESMAN: Indeed, the U.S. looks like the shining city on the hill compared to other places around the world like Europe which teetered on the verge of recession and China, where the growth was reduced. The differences were apparent in monetary policy, where the Federal Reserve took the momentous steps this year of ending its open-ended quantitative easing or bond buying program launched in September 2012.

JANET YELLEN, U.S. FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIR: Looking at unfolding economic development and as the economy strengthens, and we come closer to achieving our objectives, I think it`s very likely that we will, you know, progress on the path of normalizing policy.

LIESMAN: At the same time, the European central bank looks up to take its first step into a U.S. style Q.E. program to kick-start its economy.

MARIO DRAGHI, ECB PRESIDENT: The Q.E. program, which could include sovereign bonds, falls within our mandate, or better, is a eligible instrument that we could use in the pursue of our mandate. Not to pursue our mandate would be legal.

LIESMAN: Next year looks to be one where the Fed takes another step towards normalcy, possibly raising interest rates for the first time in eight years. But it`s not without risk, if 2014 turns out to be another false start, the Fed could be moving too early. But if growth continues to be strong, the Fed could find itself behind the curve.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I`m Steve Liesman in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: One major component of the economy, the job market, and this year, American businesses picked up their pace of hiring, turning 2014 into a solid year for job growth.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): A year ago, the national unemployment rate stood at 6.7 percent. Now, it`s down to 5.8 percent, the lowest it`s been since July of 2008. In November alone, U.S. employers added more than 320,000 jobs and 2014 is on track now to become the strongest hiring year since way back in 1999. The gains have come across all the major sectors with professional services like accountants and engineers leading the way.

Wages though have barely budged in seven years and though there have been signs of improvement recently, they are still barely keeping pace with inflation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Hampton Pearson has been covering the job market for us all year and he comes to us now from Washington, D.C.

So, Hamp, we mentioned a couple of things that we`re strong points in job creation. But from where you sit, what drove job creation this past year?

HAMPTON PEARSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it was sort of a "Little Engine That Could" syndrome, if you will, looking at all those numbers. By the way, this time last year, the month of December produced only 84,000 jobs and at the close of the Fed meeting this year, we had the Fed chairman trumping the last three months of 2014, we`ve averaged 280,000.

But to get to the core of your question, it started out with jobs essentially that did not pay all that well. It became widespread and we`re now at a point where, again, there`s some competition for skilled labor and skilled jobs and that`s actually beginning to produce some wage growth along the way as well.

And I think better job and better paying jobs will really have to be the job story of 2015.

MATHISEN: You hinted at the answer to the next question, which is about the quality of the jobs created, and you seem to be suggesting that they keep getting better and better and better.

PEARSON: Yes, we even in the November jobs report, we had a four tenths of an increase in average hourly earnings. That doesn`t sound like much, but it`s one of the biggest monthly increases we`ve seen in quite a few years. However, year over year, we`re only talking about 2 percent wage growth.

The Fed said it can live with 3 percent wage growth and still hit 2 percent inflation target. So, lots of room from a Fed standpoint, for wages to grow, and really, I think, you need the more spending power in the hands of consumers to keep the overall economy growing.

MATHISEN: So, what will it take to keep the job growth going and what could potentially throw a wrench into it?

PEARSON: More of the same, especially that near term hike we`re all getting now from lower oil prices, putting more money in people`s pockets. That too is going to boost the total demand figures in early January when we started to see what kind of holiday season we`ve had going forward.

But the road blocks along the way are, still tight labor market in some respect. Is this growth for real? Can it be sustained? You know, have we really turned a big corner here?

MATHISEN: All right, Hampton. Thank you very much. Happy holidays. Hampton Pearson --

PEARSON: Same to you.

MATHISEN: You bet -- in Washington for us.

Still ahead: the auto industry was hit by major recalls this past year, but were buyers scared away from the brands that were hit hardest?

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: The auto industry facing some of the biggest safety controversies in its history. It`s been a big year and a big focus for investors, drivers, and regulators. Topping the list, recalls of two of the biggest, the Takata airbag recall and General Motors` faulty ignition switches.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Cars and trucks are selling, almost 17 million sold this year. But recalls have auto makers reeling. The year`s biggest? About 18 million vehicles worldwide has to do with dangerous air bags made by a Japanese company, Takata. At least five deaths are blamed on those defective air bags and the recall list is still growing.

Manufacturers, meantime, have refocused on safety. In the wake of GM`s failure to deal with faulty ignition switches, blamed for some 40-plus deaths more than a decade ago. In its rearview mirror, GM can still see and feel the effects of a $35 million fine and a recall covering 15 million vehicles.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN: Phil LeBeau has been tracking the recalls and their impact on the industry and it comes to us from Chicago.

Phil, welcome.

It`s been a record year for recalls but how have those recalls affected the brands that have been hardest hit by them?

PHIL LEBEAU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it`s certainly tarnished some of the brands. General Motors (NYSE:GM) has taken a hit. Honda because it`s linked so closely with Takata, has taken a hit.

But when you look at what`s happened in terms of people coming into the showrooms, it hasn`t slowed down sales at all. And that`s primarily because these recalls for the most part has impacted older models.

And when people go into a showroom, Tyler, they have short memories. If the model that`s on the floor is not under recall, they tend to look at these recalls and say, that`s somebody else`s problem or that`s a 2008 model. I`m not looking at that. I`m looking at a 2015 model.

MATHISEN: Right, some of the ignition switch recalls, particularly so on cars that in many cases aren`t even made anymore.

LEBEAU: Right. Correct.

MATHISEN: So, with so many of these recalls, Phil, are the cars less reliable or more reliable?

LEBEAU: Actually, cars are more reliable now than they were five, ten years ago. What`s happened, Tyler, is that the globalization of the auto industry means that you have fewer suppliers and so you have a commonality of parts, so that you have one part that goes bad, and take a look at the Takata airbags as a good example, that one part goes bad, it affects millions of vehicles. And that`s what we`re seeing now, and likely will see this in the future too when recalls are announced, it will impact millions of vehicles.

MATHISEN: Let`s talk about falling gasoline prices a little bit. I think it`s in part responsible for the fact we seem to be falling in love, once again, with SUVs. The Jeep Cherokee (NASDAQ:CHKE) had a great year.

So, talk to me about that and what those gas prices may mean for more fuel efficient cars like the hybrids.

LEBEAU: Well, something like the Toyota (NYSE:TM) Prius is a perfect example. We`re going to see lower sales for the Prius and for other hybrids, and we`re already seeing that this year. It`s tougher to convince people that they should pay a slight premium to buy more fuel efficient gas electric hybrid vehicle. It`s certainly tough, Tyler, because people can sit there and say, well, why don`t I buy a compact car, I won`t have to pay $3,000 more?

However, we should point out that fuel efficiency is now part of what people look for when they`re going into the showroom. So, it`s not as if people have forgotten about what happened ten years ago when we fell in love with gas guzzler, they`re still thinking about that, but we are tending to go back towards the SUVs.

MATHISEN: Do we know anything about the aluminum bodied F-150 truck and how it`s doing, supposedly more fuel-efficient?

LEBEAU: It`s expected to be more fuel-efficient. We won`t know how the public reacts to that new truck until well into next year. We`re just seeing them trickle into showrooms. The early reviews are very positive. But that`s usually with all new vehicles.

Talk to me in the middle of next year and we`ll see how the public embraces it.

MATHISEN: All right. We`ll get back to you, Phil. Thanks very much. Philip LeBeau in Chicago.

LEBEAU: You bet.

MATHISEN: Now to the hottest industry for mergers and acquisitions. This year, health care, a changing landscape and efforts to avoid U.S. corporate taxes through so-called inversion deals, made for a very busy year for some of the biggest drug makers?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Pfizer (NYSE:PFE), Novartis, GlaxoSmithKline, Eli Lilly (NYSE:LLY), the biggest names in big pharma, all the subjects of deal talk, big deals, with tens of billions of dollars this year.

One reason: pressure on their product pipeline. It had some looking for growth outside their own company. Another reason? Taxes. Companies that could relocate to overseas addresses often get a tax break. The Washington did begin to clamp down on the so-called inversion craze with new rules in September.

The biggest of the pharma deals involve the Botox maker, Allergan (NYSE:AGN). The hedge funder Bill Ackman engineered an offer worth more than $50 billion for the company, but Allergan (NYSE:AGN) steered away and this fall, Allergan (NYSE:AGN) accepted an offer to join with Ireland`s Actavis for $66 billion.

And that wasn`t all for Actavis, which already made a deal back in July to buy another American company, Forest Labs for $28 billion.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And coming up, the Chinese e-commerce company that made its way to the New York Stock Exchange and became the biggest initial public offering ever.

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: Perhaps the biggest stock story of the year with Alibaba`s initial public offering. Not only did it introduce investors to its CEO Jack Ma, colorful guy, but it also claimed the title biggest IPO ever.

Kayla Tausche was at the New York Stock Exchange on the very day it started trading.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KAYLA TAUSCHE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Alibaba is off and running. The Chinese ecommerce giant soaring above $90 in its debut after pricing for $68 a share.

The company founded in the apartment of entrepreneur Jack Ma in 1999 with just a dozen partners now responsible for 80 percent of China`s ecommerce and valued today by the public market in the United States at $240 billion.

Alibaba`s business model is often described as a mash up between Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and eBay (NASDAQ:EBAY), but it`s now is a formidable challenge to tech companies here in the U.S. It`s bigger than Disney (NYSE:DIS), IBM and JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase.

But Ma said he draws inspiration from another U.S. corporation.

JACK MA, ALIBABA FOUNDER: We hope in the next 50 years, the world change because of that. We want to be bigger than Walmart. We want to be bigger -- it`s not just the size, we want to learn from Walmart. They changed the business last century. They stressed the B2C.

And we hope, 15 years later, they say, this is a company like a Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT), like IBM, like Walmart. They changed and shaped the world.

TAUSCHE (on camera): Alibaba`s platform sold $259 billion in goods last year and its vendors were responsible for 60 percent of all packages shipped in China. Alibaba helped small businesses connect to new customers and in turn buttressing China`s middle class.

(voice-over): That`s the main reason why investors have been clamoring for shares. They`re willing to pay much more than the $68 IPO price set by the company, formally minting Hangzhou`s Jack Ma as the richest man in mainland China.

But his fight to grow Alibaba is still centered on the little guy, when he`s often reminded of by a famous movie character.

MA: The hero I had was Forrest Gump. And I watched the movie before I came here again, before -- for coming to New York, because I watched the movie again, telling me that no matter, whatever changed, you are you. And I`m still the guy 15 years ago.

TAUSCHE: Alibaba, of course, is now far bigger.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And Kayla Tausche with us now for more on Alibaba and the other big tech stories of the year.

You know, Alibaba, the IPO, biggest ever, came off seemingly without a hitch. How did it change the landscape and the willingness for people to back these big IPOs?

TAUSCHE: You know, people were a little bit hesitant to see a company that was technically based in the Cayman Islands, with the bulk of its business in China, now trading here on U.S. soil. But investors really bought the story. They clamored to get the shares.

And when I talk to bankers on the day of the IPO, they said twice as many orders for shares of Alibaba coming from U.S. retail investors than they were for shares of Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Tyler. This has become a household name and it`s really broken down the borders of ecommerce, this company that really was an upstart, came from nowhere, and all of the sudden, is bigger --

MATHISEN: Household name in China, but is it ever going to be a household name and a big player in the U.S.? What do you think?

TAUSCHE: The expectation is that it will and the demand from U.S. investors through their retail financial advisors trying to get these shares just shows you that it is starting to pick up a little bit. Now, it`s bigger than JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase. It`s bigger than Facebook (NASDAQ:FB).

MATHISEN: What?

TAUSCHE: When you think about that market cap, Jack Ma was just saying in that piece, he wants to be bigger than Walmart. Well, his stock already is.

MATHISEN: All right. Now, explain to me the other one that maybe on the radar screen for 2015, and that is Uber, the ride-sharing service. The valuations that are being tossed around for this company, if it does indeed go public this year, are astronomical for what I think is a taxi service. I don`t get it.

TAUSCHE: Well, the key to something like Uber and the reason why now is the time that a company like Uber can grow so much is this little tool right here, this smartphone. This wouldn`t have been the power behind a company like Uber were we talking about five years ago.

But Uber is now worth $40 billion. Just six months ago, it was worth $18 billion, which even then sounded like an astounding number. A year and a half, worth $3.5 billion but investors say the earnings back that up that Uber in a year`s time could make $10 billion in bookings because people say, hey, I don`t want to get stuck in traffic. I`d like to have someone drive me and --

MATHISEN: Do you use it?

TAUSCHE: I do.

MATHISEN: I use it too.

TAUSCHE: And if the cost is comparable to a taxi, why not?

MATHISEN: All right. Kayla, thanks very much. Have a good New Year. All right. Thanks, everybody, for watching this special holiday edition of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I`m Tyler Mathisen. Have a great evening, everybody. And we`ll hope to see you right back here tomorrow night.

ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Susie Gharib, funded in part by --

(COMMERCIAL AD)

TYLER MATHISEN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Welcome to this special holiday of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I'm Tyler Mathisen. Susie Gharib has the night off.

Well, 2014 is almost in the books and it's been filled with highs, many of them closing highs for the major indexes and lows like plummeting crude oil prices. But that wasn't all that happened this year in the world of business. The economy and the job market hit a number of milestones as well. The health care sector dominated deal making, recalls roiled the auto business and a Chinese e-commerce company called Alibaba became the biggest IPO ever.

Tonight, we look back on 2014, the year that was.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): With the Dow notching record highs more than 30 times and the S&P about 50, the bull market is now more than 5 years old. But 2013's perpetual push upward bumped into appear old acquaintance, volatility.

In November, stocks bounced up to new highs, but in December, there was another slide. Stock prices wavered just as the Federal Reserve prepared to end its economic stimulus program. Talk of the taper hung over the markets like a cloud a year ago. Now, it's still about the Fed but the question is when it will begin to push interest rates back up?

Can the economy handle higher interest rates? Well, employment numbers are better but real incomes really aren't and inflation is still below the Fed's target level of 2 percent.

One reason for the low inflation: a historic drop in the price of oil, down more than 45 percent from the year's high in June. Why? Well, it is simple and complex as the law of supply and demand. Supply is up. The U.S. alone has increased production 65 percent in just five years. Demand, though, is decidedly down, because the global economy is slowing.

Here at home, the drop in oil pushed gas prices down by a dollar a gallon and more in some places. Cheaper gas, of course, puts an estimated $100 billion back into the hands of U.S. consumers. That's about 60 bucks a month for the typical household. But is that enough to get them spending again? Money still tight for most of us.

So, where is the U.S. finding growth? Companies are still sitting on record piles of cash. Some of that money is staying overseas as the wait for U.S. corporate tax reform lingers on.

But there's plenty of money to invest in the latest technologies and corporate spending is helping to grow the economy. Tech is booming. Silicon Valley is a world leader. Apple's new iPhones are a huge hit. In Seattle, Boeing (NYSE:BA) gets orders for more than fuel efficient jets from all over the globe and Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) expanded in New York City, which is suddenly flush with more than 4 million jobs, the most the Big Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) has ever had.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Quite a year. And we'll start with Wall Street. The bull market, of course, proved it was alive and kicking. Major indexes closing at numerous records, almost too many to count, but it's hard to talk about the stock market without touching on what may be the biggest story of the year for investors, oil prices.

So, with us, Dom Chu to focus on the stock market, Jackie DeAngelis on energy.

Welcome to you both. Happy holidays.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Happy holidays.

MATHISEN: Let me start with you, Dom. Sum it up in a few sentences for us.

DOMINIC CHU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you talk about the market, you cannot forget that we've hit record highs upon record highs, like you said.

So, as we look at what's happening in 2014, this bull run is very much intact. But it was this time around, it wasn't so much a lot of the technology names that we talked about before. It was health care that was a real driver for the market this time around. Those stocks, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals alike, a lot of deal-making like you said, all of that drove that to be the best performing sector in the S&P 500.

Of course, with those record highs, a lot of investors are calling to question whether or not they can sustain that going into 2015. Of course, the trend has been positive for a lot of them so far.

MATHISEN: You know, and when you look at those sectors, almost all of them higher except the one you follow most closely, which is energy. And were not for the falling oil prices, presumably, energy would be higher.

CHU: It's been a huge drag, of course.

MATHISEN: Huge drag.

Lots of factors, we talked there in the piece about supply and demand. Is it really as simple as that?

DEANGELIS: It really is as simple as that. And, actually, I don't think investors were expecting energy to be the story that it was in the back half of the year.

It certainly was no secret that supply was ramping the way analysts were expecting it to. As a matter of fact, this year, we finally started producing over 9 million barrels a day. That is almost up to the point of what Saudi Arabia's output is. We never thought we'd be at that level.

At the same time, the demands part of the equation is what took us off guard. When the demand started to fall off, that's prices started to decline. The question right now is, how do we curtail the supply to be able to meet the demand? Does the demand equation change in 2015 so that supply should stay stable right now? These are all the unknowns.

MATHISEN: Let's talk a little bit about OPEC. Have they become irrelevant?

DEANGELIS: A lot of people are thinking the OPEC is becoming irrelevant but I would say the last meeting in November really changed the game. When they did not change their stance in terms of production and prices really tanked even further, OPEC was sort of showing some muscle and flexing it and saying, look, we're in this game.

MATHISEN: So, what's their end game? Is what they really to do, to squeeze out the higher cost U.S. producers or squeeze them so they scream?

DEANGELIS: I think what they're worried about for themselves is losing shares. So, right now, they're saying, we're going to eat the price decline but we are going to hold on to market share. And if that squeezes shale, it squeezes shale. This is going to be a game of chicken, every man for itself, and it could get really ugly.

MATHISEN: Back to stocks. Falling oil prices really thought to be a net positive for the economy.

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: But in recent weeks, as oil has receded, collapsed in some people's view --

CHU: Of course.

MATHISEN: -- equities hit a hard spot.

CHU: I mean, here, the numbers are quite staggering. Because just this quarter alone, the last quarter, and we're only in the middle, we haven't finished December at this point. By mid-December just in the S&P 500 energy companies alone, that oil price decline left the decline in stocks of all varieties in the energy sector. So much so that just this quarter to date, we've lost about $265 billion, with a B, dollars worth of market values for these energy companies.

So, this slide in oil price is huge. But it's also important to remember that the driver for the economy right now, oil is a big part of it but it's smaller part of the overall index than say, technology and financial stocks. Those two sectors are the most heavily weighted in the index. You want to see leadership there. If oil prices can rebound, that's great as well.

MATHISEN: So, let's spin in ahead here.

Why don't you go first, Jackie? What is the outlook for energy prices over the first six months or all of 2015?

DEANGELIS: Well, for the first six months, certainly, analysts and traders alike are saying we could potentially go lower from here. Nobody really wants to call the bottom just yet until again, they get a sense of where this story is going, until some of the data shows us if the demand is going to come back on the table.

Having said that, people have also said to me, you know, once we do hit the bottom, maybe it's somewhere in the 40s. We will rebound quickly back to the $60 or $70 range. So, that probably could happen in the back half of the year.

MATHISEN: And for you, Dom, we got back last week guidance from the Fed on interest rates.

CHU: We did.

MATHISEN: What's the outlook for stock prices 2015?

CHU: Well, for 2015, what you're seeing a lot of experts say is that you're going to see the same level of valuation in the overall market, but it's going to match earnings' growth. Earnings growth is not expected to be gang-busters but it's still expected to grow. So, a lot of experts are seeing, yes, gains in the stock market. But you're not talking about the 10 percent, 15 percent, 20 percent return varieties. You're talking about --

MATHISEN: The profit growth and dividend.

CHU: -- maybe that 5 percent, 6 percent, 7 percent. Yes.

MATHISEN: Dom and Jackie, thanks very much. Appreciate it.

All righty. Now, to the economy, which is being helped by those low energy prices we just mentioned. But they didn't start out that way. If anything, the brutal winners slammed the brakes on much of the country's economic activity. But then the growth engine was turned on.

Steve Liesman reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Five long years after the end of the recession, a period marked by sluggish growth and stubbornly high unemployment, the U.S. economy may have turned a corner in 2014. Beginning the year with a surprise decline in growth, attributed to weather but causing many to say, here we go again. The U.S. economy proceeded to rocket ahead, tallying its best two quarters of growth since in 2003, and on track for its best year of job gains since 2000.

Unlike previous post-crisis growth spurts, this time it didn't appear, the gains would be given back.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's pretty hard to find an economic measure where we're not significantly better off. I don't have to tell you about the stock market and where that's gone, corporate profits, record highs. But also, unemployment now lower than it was previously. We've seen the housing market recover, although not as fast as we'd like, the auto industry recovering. We remain the most dynamic, innovative economy in the world.

LIESMAN: Indeed, the U.S. looks like the shining city on the hill compared to other places around the world like Europe which teetered on the verge of recession and China, where the growth was reduced. The differences were apparent in monetary policy, where the Federal Reserve took the momentous steps this year of ending its open-ended quantitative easing or bond buying program launched in September 2012.

JANET YELLEN, U.S. FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIR: Looking at unfolding economic development and as the economy strengthens, and we come closer to achieving our objectives, I think it's very likely that we will, you know, progress on the path of normalizing policy.

LIESMAN: At the same time, the European central bank looks up to take its first step into a U.S. style Q.E. program to kick-start its economy.

MARIO DRAGHI, ECB PRESIDENT: The Q.E. program, which could include sovereign bonds, falls within our mandate, or better, is a eligible instrument that we could use in the pursue of our mandate. Not to pursue our mandate would be legal.

LIESMAN: Next year looks to be one where the Fed takes another step towards normalcy, possibly raising interest rates for the first time in eight years. But it's not without risk, if 2014 turns out to be another false start, the Fed could be moving too early. But if growth continues to be strong, the Fed could find itself behind the curve.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Steve Liesman in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: One major component of the economy, the job market, and this year, American businesses picked up their pace of hiring, turning 2014 into a solid year for job growth.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): A year ago, the national unemployment rate stood at 6.7 percent. Now, it's down to 5.8 percent, the lowest it's been since July of 2008. In November alone, U.S. employers added more than 320,000 jobs and 2014 is on track now to become the strongest hiring year since way back in 1999. The gains have come across all the major sectors with professional services like accountants and engineers leading the way.

Wages though have barely budged in seven years and though there have been signs of improvement recently, they are still barely keeping pace with inflation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Hampton Pearson has been covering the job market for us all year and he comes to us now from Washington, D.C.

So, Hamp, we mentioned a couple of things that we're strong points in job creation. But from where you sit, what drove job creation this past year?

HAMPTON PEARSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it was sort of a "Little Engine That Could" syndrome, if you will, looking at all those numbers. By the way, this time last year, the month of December produced only 84,000 jobs and at the close of the Fed meeting this year, we had the Fed chairman trumping the last three months of 2014, we've averaged 280,000.

But to get to the core of your question, it started out with jobs essentially that did not pay all that well. It became widespread and we're now at a point where, again, there's some competition for skilled labor and skilled jobs and that's actually beginning to produce some wage growth along the way as well.

And I think better job and better paying jobs will really have to be the job story of 2015.

MATHISEN: You hinted at the answer to the next question, which is about the quality of the jobs created, and you seem to be suggesting that they keep getting better and better and better.

PEARSON: Yes, we even in the November jobs report, we had a four tenths of an increase in average hourly earnings. That doesn't sound like much, but it's one of the biggest monthly increases we've seen in quite a few years. However, year over year, we're only talking about 2 percent wage growth.

The Fed said it can live with 3 percent wage growth and still hit 2 percent inflation target. So, lots of room from a Fed standpoint, for wages to grow, and really, I think, you need the more spending power in the hands of consumers to keep the overall economy growing.

MATHISEN: So, what will it take to keep the job growth going and what could potentially throw a wrench into it?

PEARSON: More of the same, especially that near term hike we're all getting now from lower oil prices, putting more money in people's pockets. That too is going to boost the total demand figures in early January when we started to see what kind of holiday season we've had going forward.

But the road blocks along the way are, still tight labor market in some respect. Is this growth for real? Can it be sustained? You know, have we really turned a big corner here?

MATHISEN: All right, Hampton. Thank you very much. Happy holidays. Hampton Pearson --

PEARSON: Same to you.

MATHISEN: You bet -- in Washington for us.

Still ahead: the auto industry was hit by major recalls this past year, but were buyers scared away from the brands that were hit hardest?

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: The auto industry facing some of the biggest safety controversies in its history. It's been a big year and a big focus for investors, drivers, and regulators. Topping the list, recalls of two of the biggest, the Takata airbag recall and General Motors' faulty ignition switches.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Cars and trucks are selling, almost 17 million sold this year. But recalls have auto makers reeling. The year's biggest? About 18 million vehicles worldwide has to do with dangerous air bags made by a Japanese company, Takata. At least five deaths are blamed on those defective air bags and the recall list is still growing.

Manufacturers, meantime, have refocused on safety. In the wake of GM's failure to deal with faulty ignition switches, blamed for some 40-plus deaths more than a decade ago. In its rearview mirror, GM can still see and feel the effects of a $35 million fine and a recall covering 15 million vehicles.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN: Phil LeBeau has been tracking the recalls and their impact on the industry and it comes to us from Chicago.

Phil, welcome.

It's been a record year for recalls but how have those recalls affected the brands that have been hardest hit by them?

PHIL LEBEAU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it's certainly tarnished some of the brands. General Motors (NYSE:GM) has taken a hit. Honda because it's linked so closely with Takata, has taken a hit.

But when you look at what's happened in terms of people coming into the showrooms, it hasn't slowed down sales at all. And that's primarily because these recalls for the most part has impacted older models.

And when people go into a showroom, Tyler, they have short memories. If the model that's on the floor is not under recall, they tend to look at these recalls and say, that's somebody else's problem or that's a 2008 model. I'm not looking at that. I'm looking at a 2015 model.

MATHISEN: Right, some of the ignition switch recalls, particularly so on cars that in many cases aren't even made anymore.

LEBEAU: Right. Correct.

MATHISEN: So, with so many of these recalls, Phil, are the cars less reliable or more reliable?

LEBEAU: Actually, cars are more reliable now than they were five, ten years ago. What's happened, Tyler, is that the globalization of the auto industry means that you have fewer suppliers and so you have a commonality of parts, so that you have one part that goes bad, and take a look at the Takata airbags as a good example, that one part goes bad, it affects millions of vehicles. And that's what we're seeing now, and likely will see this in the future too when recalls are announced, it will impact millions of vehicles.

MATHISEN: Let's talk about falling gasoline prices a little bit. I think it's in part responsible for the fact we seem to be falling in love, once again, with SUVs. The Jeep Cherokee (NASDAQ:CHKE) had a great year.

So, talk to me about that and what those gas prices may mean for more fuel efficient cars like the hybrids.

LEBEAU: Well, something like the Toyota (NYSE:TM) Prius is a perfect example. We're going to see lower sales for the Prius and for other hybrids, and we're already seeing that this year. It's tougher to convince people that they should pay a slight premium to buy more fuel efficient gas electric hybrid vehicle. It's certainly tough, Tyler, because people can sit there and say, well, why don't I buy a compact car, I won't have to pay $3,000 more?

However, we should point out that fuel efficiency is now part of what people look for when they're going into the showroom. So, it's not as if people have forgotten about what happened ten years ago when we fell in love with gas guzzler, they're still thinking about that, but we are tending to go back towards the SUVs.

MATHISEN: Do we know anything about the aluminum bodied F-150 truck and how it's doing, supposedly more fuel-efficient?

LEBEAU: It's expected to be more fuel-efficient. We won't know how the public reacts to that new truck until well into next year. We're just seeing them trickle into showrooms. The early reviews are very positive. But that's usually with all new vehicles.

Talk to me in the middle of next year and we'll see how the public embraces it.

MATHISEN: All right. We'll get back to you, Phil. Thanks very much. Philip LeBeau in Chicago.

LEBEAU: You bet.

MATHISEN: Now to the hottest industry for mergers and acquisitions. This year, health care, a changing landscape and efforts to avoid U.S. corporate taxes through so-called inversion deals, made for a very busy year for some of the biggest drug makers?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Pfizer (NYSE:PFE), Novartis, GlaxoSmithKline, Eli Lilly (NYSE:LLY), the biggest names in big pharma, all the subjects of deal talk, big deals, with tens of billions of dollars this year.

One reason: pressure on their product pipeline. It had some looking for growth outside their own company. Another reason? Taxes. Companies that could relocate to overseas addresses often get a tax break. The Washington did begin to clamp down on the so-called inversion craze with new rules in September.

The biggest of the pharma deals involve the Botox maker, Allergan (NYSE:AGN). The hedge funder Bill Ackman engineered an offer worth more than $50 billion for the company, but Allergan (NYSE:AGN) steered away and this fall, Allergan (NYSE:AGN) accepted an offer to join with Ireland's Actavis for $66 billion.

And that wasn't all for Actavis, which already made a deal back in July to buy another American company, Forest Labs for $28 billion.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And coming up, the Chinese e-commerce company that made its way to the New York Stock Exchange and became the biggest initial public offering ever.

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: Perhaps the biggest stock story of the year with Alibaba's initial public offering. Not only did it introduce investors to its CEO Jack Ma, colorful guy, but it also claimed the title biggest IPO ever.

Kayla Tausche was at the New York Stock Exchange on the very day it started trading.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KAYLA TAUSCHE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Alibaba is off and running. The Chinese ecommerce giant soaring above $90 in its debut after pricing for $68 a share.

The company founded in the apartment of entrepreneur Jack Ma in 1999 with just a dozen partners now responsible for 80 percent of China's ecommerce and valued today by the public market in the United States at $240 billion.

Alibaba's business model is often described as a mash up between Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and eBay (NASDAQ:EBAY), but it's now is a formidable challenge to tech companies here in the U.S. It's bigger than Disney (NYSE:DIS), IBM and JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase.

But Ma said he draws inspiration from another U.S. corporation.

JACK MA, ALIBABA FOUNDER: We hope in the next 50 years, the world change because of that. We want to be bigger than Walmart. We want to be bigger -- it's not just the size, we want to learn from Walmart. They changed the business last century. They stressed the B2C.

And we hope, 15 years later, they say, this is a company like a Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT), like IBM, like Walmart. They changed and shaped the world.

TAUSCHE (on camera): Alibaba's platform sold $259 billion in goods last year and its vendors were responsible for 60 percent of all packages shipped in China. Alibaba helped small businesses connect to new customers and in turn buttressing China's middle class.

(voice-over): That's the main reason why investors have been clamoring for shares. They're willing to pay much more than the $68 IPO price set by the company, formally minting Hangzhou's Jack Ma as the richest man in mainland China.

But his fight to grow Alibaba is still centered on the little guy, when he's often reminded of by a famous movie character.

MA: The hero I had was Forrest Gump. And I watched the movie before I came here again, before -- for coming to New York, because I watched the movie again, telling me that no matter, whatever changed, you are you. And I'm still the guy 15 years ago.

TAUSCHE: Alibaba, of course, is now far bigger.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And Kayla Tausche with us now for more on Alibaba and the other big tech stories of the year.

You know, Alibaba, the IPO, biggest ever, came off seemingly without a hitch. How did it change the landscape and the willingness for people to back these big IPOs?

TAUSCHE: You know, people were a little bit hesitant to see a company that was technically based in the Cayman Islands, with the bulk of its business in China, now trading here on U.S. soil. But investors really bought the story. They clamored to get the shares.

And when I talk to bankers on the day of the IPO, they said twice as many orders for shares of Alibaba coming from U.S. retail investors than they were for shares of Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Tyler. This has become a household name and it's really broken down the borders of ecommerce, this company that really was an upstart, came from nowhere, and all of the sudden, is bigger --

MATHISEN: Household name in China, but is it ever going to be a household name and a big player in the U.S.? What do you think?

TAUSCHE: The expectation is that it will and the demand from U.S. investors through their retail financial advisors trying to get these shares just shows you that it is starting to pick up a little bit. Now, it's bigger than JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase. It's bigger than Facebook (NASDAQ:FB).

MATHISEN: What?

TAUSCHE: When you think about that market cap, Jack Ma was just saying in that piece, he wants to be bigger than Walmart. Well, his stock already is.

MATHISEN: All right. Now, explain to me the other one that maybe on the radar screen for 2015, and that is Uber, the ride-sharing service. The valuations that are being tossed around for this company, if it does indeed go public this year, are astronomical for what I think is a taxi service. I don't get it.

TAUSCHE: Well, the key to something like Uber and the reason why now is the time that a company like Uber can grow so much is this little tool right here, this smartphone. This wouldn't have been the power behind a company like Uber were we talking about five years ago.

But Uber is now worth $40 billion. Just six months ago, it was worth $18 billion, which even then sounded like an astounding number. A year and a half, worth $3.5 billion but investors say the earnings back that up that Uber in a year's time could make $10 billion in bookings because people say, hey, I don't want to get stuck in traffic. I'd like to have someone drive me and --

MATHISEN: Do you use it?

TAUSCHE: I do.

MATHISEN: I use it too.

TAUSCHE: And if the cost is comparable to a taxi, why not?

MATHISEN: All right. Kayla, thanks very much. Have a good New Year. All right. Thanks, everybody, for watching this special holiday edition of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I'm Tyler Mathisen. Have a great evening, everybody. And we'll hope to see you right back here tomorrow night.

END

ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Susie Gharib, funded in part by --

(COMMERCIAL AD)

TYLER MATHISEN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Welcome to this special holiday of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I'm Tyler Mathisen. Susie Gharib has the night off.

Well, 2014 is almost in the books and it's been filled with highs, many of them closing highs for the major indexes and lows like plummeting crude oil prices. But that wasn't all that happened this year in the world of business. The economy and the job market hit a number of milestones as well. The health care sector dominated deal making, recalls roiled the auto business and a Chinese e-commerce company called Alibaba became the biggest IPO ever.

Tonight, we look back on 2014, the year that was.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): With the Dow notching record highs more than 30 times and the S&P about 50, the bull market is now more than 5 years old. But 2013's perpetual push upward bumped into appear old acquaintance, volatility.

In November, stocks bounced up to new highs, but in December, there was another slide. Stock prices wavered just as the Federal Reserve prepared to end its economic stimulus program. Talk of the taper hung over the markets like a cloud a year ago. Now, it's still about the Fed but the question is when it will begin to push interest rates back up?

Can the economy handle higher interest rates? Well, employment numbers are better but real incomes really aren't and inflation is still below the Fed's target level of 2 percent.

One reason for the low inflation: a historic drop in the price of oil, down more than 45 percent from the year's high in June. Why? Well, it is simple and complex as the law of supply and demand. Supply is up. The U.S. alone has increased production 65 percent in just five years. Demand, though, is decidedly down, because the global economy is slowing.

Here at home, the drop in oil pushed gas prices down by a dollar a gallon and more in some places. Cheaper gas, of course, puts an estimated $100 billion back into the hands of U.S. consumers. That's about 60 bucks a month for the typical household. But is that enough to get them spending again? Money still tight for most of us.

So, where is the U.S. finding growth? Companies are still sitting on record piles of cash. Some of that money is staying overseas as the wait for U.S. corporate tax reform lingers on.

But there's plenty of money to invest in the latest technologies and corporate spending is helping to grow the economy. Tech is booming. Silicon Valley is a world leader. Apple's new iPhones are a huge hit. In Seattle, Boeing (NYSE:BA) gets orders for more than fuel efficient jets from all over the globe and Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) expanded in New York City, which is suddenly flush with more than 4 million jobs, the most the Big Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) has ever had.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Quite a year. And we'll start with Wall Street. The bull market, of course, proved it was alive and kicking. Major indexes closing at numerous records, almost too many to count, but it's hard to talk about the stock market without touching on what may be the biggest story of the year for investors, oil prices.

So, with us, Dom Chu to focus on the stock market, Jackie DeAngelis on energy.

Welcome to you both. Happy holidays.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Happy holidays.

MATHISEN: Let me start with you, Dom. Sum it up in a few sentences for us.

DOMINIC CHU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you talk about the market, you cannot forget that we've hit record highs upon record highs, like you said.

So, as we look at what's happening in 2014, this bull run is very much intact. But it was this time around, it wasn't so much a lot of the technology names that we talked about before. It was health care that was a real driver for the market this time around. Those stocks, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals alike, a lot of deal-making like you said, all of that drove that to be the best performing sector in the S&P 500.

Of course, with those record highs, a lot of investors are calling to question whether or not they can sustain that going into 2015. Of course, the trend has been positive for a lot of them so far.

MATHISEN: You know, and when you look at those sectors, almost all of them higher except the one you follow most closely, which is energy. And were not for the falling oil prices, presumably, energy would be higher.

CHU: It's been a huge drag, of course.

MATHISEN: Huge drag.

Lots of factors, we talked there in the piece about supply and demand. Is it really as simple as that?

DEANGELIS: It really is as simple as that. And, actually, I don't think investors were expecting energy to be the story that it was in the back half of the year.

It certainly was no secret that supply was ramping the way analysts were expecting it to. As a matter of fact, this year, we finally started producing over 9 million barrels a day. That is almost up to the point of what Saudi Arabia's output is. We never thought we'd be at that level.

At the same time, the demands part of the equation is what took us off guard. When the demand started to fall off, that's prices started to decline. The question right now is, how do we curtail the supply to be able to meet the demand? Does the demand equation change in 2015 so that supply should stay stable right now? These are all the unknowns.

MATHISEN: Let's talk a little bit about OPEC. Have they become irrelevant?

DEANGELIS: A lot of people are thinking the OPEC is becoming irrelevant but I would say the last meeting in November really changed the game. When they did not change their stance in terms of production and prices really tanked even further, OPEC was sort of showing some muscle and flexing it and saying, look, we're in this game.

MATHISEN: So, what's their end game? Is what they really to do, to squeeze out the higher cost U.S. producers or squeeze them so they scream?

DEANGELIS: I think what they're worried about for themselves is losing shares. So, right now, they're saying, we're going to eat the price decline but we are going to hold on to market share. And if that squeezes shale, it squeezes shale. This is going to be a game of chicken, every man for itself, and it could get really ugly.

MATHISEN: Back to stocks. Falling oil prices really thought to be a net positive for the economy.

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: But in recent weeks, as oil has receded, collapsed in some people's view --

CHU: Of course.

MATHISEN: -- equities hit a hard spot.

CHU: I mean, here, the numbers are quite staggering. Because just this quarter alone, the last quarter, and we're only in the middle, we haven't finished December at this point. By mid-December just in the S&P 500 energy companies alone, that oil price decline left the decline in stocks of all varieties in the energy sector. So much so that just this quarter to date, we've lost about $265 billion, with a B, dollars worth of market values for these energy companies.

So, this slide in oil price is huge. But it's also important to remember that the driver for the economy right now, oil is a big part of it but it's smaller part of the overall index than say, technology and financial stocks. Those two sectors are the most heavily weighted in the index. You want to see leadership there. If oil prices can rebound, that's great as well.

MATHISEN: So, let's spin in ahead here.

Why don't you go first, Jackie? What is the outlook for energy prices over the first six months or all of 2015?

DEANGELIS: Well, for the first six months, certainly, analysts and traders alike are saying we could potentially go lower from here. Nobody really wants to call the bottom just yet until again, they get a sense of where this story is going, until some of the data shows us if the demand is going to come back on the table.

Having said that, people have also said to me, you know, once we do hit the bottom, maybe it's somewhere in the 40s. We will rebound quickly back to the $60 or $70 range. So, that probably could happen in the back half of the year.

MATHISEN: And for you, Dom, we got back last week guidance from the Fed on interest rates.

CHU: We did.

MATHISEN: What's the outlook for stock prices 2015?

CHU: Well, for 2015, what you're seeing a lot of experts say is that you're going to see the same level of valuation in the overall market, but it's going to match earnings' growth. Earnings growth is not expected to be gang-busters but it's still expected to grow. So, a lot of experts are seeing, yes, gains in the stock market. But you're not talking about the 10 percent, 15 percent, 20 percent return varieties. You're talking about --

MATHISEN: The profit growth and dividend.

CHU: -- maybe that 5 percent, 6 percent, 7 percent. Yes.

MATHISEN: Dom and Jackie, thanks very much. Appreciate it.

All righty. Now, to the economy, which is being helped by those low energy prices we just mentioned. But they didn't start out that way. If anything, the brutal winners slammed the brakes on much of the country's economic activity. But then the growth engine was turned on.

Steve Liesman reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Five long years after the end of the recession, a period marked by sluggish growth and stubbornly high unemployment, the U.S. economy may have turned a corner in 2014. Beginning the year with a surprise decline in growth, attributed to weather but causing many to say, here we go again. The U.S. economy proceeded to rocket ahead, tallying its best two quarters of growth since in 2003, and on track for its best year of job gains since 2000.

Unlike previous post-crisis growth spurts, this time it didn't appear, the gains would be given back.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's pretty hard to find an economic measure where we're not significantly better off. I don't have to tell you about the stock market and where that's gone, corporate profits, record highs. But also, unemployment now lower than it was previously. We've seen the housing market recover, although not as fast as we'd like, the auto industry recovering. We remain the most dynamic, innovative economy in the world.

LIESMAN: Indeed, the U.S. looks like the shining city on the hill compared to other places around the world like Europe which teetered on the verge of recession and China, where the growth was reduced. The differences were apparent in monetary policy, where the Federal Reserve took the momentous steps this year of ending its open-ended quantitative easing or bond buying program launched in September 2012.

JANET YELLEN, U.S. FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIR: Looking at unfolding economic development and as the economy strengthens, and we come closer to achieving our objectives, I think it's very likely that we will, you know, progress on the path of normalizing policy.

LIESMAN: At the same time, the European central bank looks up to take its first step into a U.S. style Q.E. program to kick-start its economy.

MARIO DRAGHI, ECB PRESIDENT: The Q.E. program, which could include sovereign bonds, falls within our mandate, or better, is a eligible instrument that we could use in the pursue of our mandate. Not to pursue our mandate would be legal.

LIESMAN: Next year looks to be one where the Fed takes another step towards normalcy, possibly raising interest rates for the first time in eight years. But it's not without risk, if 2014 turns out to be another false start, the Fed could be moving too early. But if growth continues to be strong, the Fed could find itself behind the curve.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Steve Liesman in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: One major component of the economy, the job market, and this year, American businesses picked up their pace of hiring, turning 2014 into a solid year for job growth.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): A year ago, the national unemployment rate stood at 6.7 percent. Now, it's down to 5.8 percent, the lowest it's been since July of 2008. In November alone, U.S. employers added more than 320,000 jobs and 2014 is on track now to become the strongest hiring year since way back in 1999. The gains have come across all the major sectors with professional services like accountants and engineers leading the way.

Wages though have barely budged in seven years and though there have been signs of improvement recently, they are still barely keeping pace with inflation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Hampton Pearson has been covering the job market for us all year and he comes to us now from Washington, D.C.

So, Hamp, we mentioned a couple of things that we're strong points in job creation. But from where you sit, what drove job creation this past year?

HAMPTON PEARSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it was sort of a "Little Engine That Could" syndrome, if you will, looking at all those numbers. By the way, this time last year, the month of December produced only 84,000 jobs and at the close of the Fed meeting this year, we had the Fed chairman trumping the last three months of 2014, we've averaged 280,000.

But to get to the core of your question, it started out with jobs essentially that did not pay all that well. It became widespread and we're now at a point where, again, there's some competition for skilled labor and skilled jobs and that's actually beginning to produce some wage growth along the way as well.

And I think better job and better paying jobs will really have to be the job story of 2015.

MATHISEN: You hinted at the answer to the next question, which is about the quality of the jobs created, and you seem to be suggesting that they keep getting better and better and better.

PEARSON: Yes, we even in the November jobs report, we had a four tenths of an increase in average hourly earnings. That doesn't sound like much, but it's one of the biggest monthly increases we've seen in quite a few years. However, year over year, we're only talking about 2 percent wage growth.

The Fed said it can live with 3 percent wage growth and still hit 2 percent inflation target. So, lots of room from a Fed standpoint, for wages to grow, and really, I think, you need the more spending power in the hands of consumers to keep the overall economy growing.

MATHISEN: So, what will it take to keep the job growth going and what could potentially throw a wrench into it?

PEARSON: More of the same, especially that near term hike we're all getting now from lower oil prices, putting more money in people's pockets. That too is going to boost the total demand figures in early January when we started to see what kind of holiday season we've had going forward.

But the road blocks along the way are, still tight labor market in some respect. Is this growth for real? Can it be sustained? You know, have we really turned a big corner here?

MATHISEN: All right, Hampton. Thank you very much. Happy holidays. Hampton Pearson --

PEARSON: Same to you.

MATHISEN: You bet -- in Washington for us.

Still ahead: the auto industry was hit by major recalls this past year, but were buyers scared away from the brands that were hit hardest?

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: The auto industry facing some of the biggest safety controversies in its history. It's been a big year and a big focus for investors, drivers, and regulators. Topping the list, recalls of two of the biggest, the Takata airbag recall and General Motors' faulty ignition switches.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Cars and trucks are selling, almost 17 million sold this year. But recalls have auto makers reeling. The year's biggest? About 18 million vehicles worldwide has to do with dangerous air bags made by a Japanese company, Takata. At least five deaths are blamed on those defective air bags and the recall list is still growing.

Manufacturers, meantime, have refocused on safety. In the wake of GM's failure to deal with faulty ignition switches, blamed for some 40-plus deaths more than a decade ago. In its rearview mirror, GM can still see and feel the effects of a $35 million fine and a recall covering 15 million vehicles.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN: Phil LeBeau has been tracking the recalls and their impact on the industry and it comes to us from Chicago.

Phil, welcome.

It's been a record year for recalls but how have those recalls affected the brands that have been hardest hit by them?

PHIL LEBEAU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, it's certainly tarnished some of the brands. General Motors (NYSE:GM) has taken a hit. Honda because it's linked so closely with Takata, has taken a hit.

But when you look at what's happened in terms of people coming into the showrooms, it hasn't slowed down sales at all. And that's primarily because these recalls for the most part has impacted older models.

And when people go into a showroom, Tyler, they have short memories. If the model that's on the floor is not under recall, they tend to look at these recalls and say, that's somebody else's problem or that's a 2008 model. I'm not looking at that. I'm looking at a 2015 model.

MATHISEN: Right, some of the ignition switch recalls, particularly so on cars that in many cases aren't even made anymore.

LEBEAU: Right. Correct.

MATHISEN: So, with so many of these recalls, Phil, are the cars less reliable or more reliable?

LEBEAU: Actually, cars are more reliable now than they were five, ten years ago. What's happened, Tyler, is that the globalization of the auto industry means that you have fewer suppliers and so you have a commonality of parts, so that you have one part that goes bad, and take a look at the Takata airbags as a good example, that one part goes bad, it affects millions of vehicles. And that's what we're seeing now, and likely will see this in the future too when recalls are announced, it will impact millions of vehicles.

MATHISEN: Let's talk about falling gasoline prices a little bit. I think it's in part responsible for the fact we seem to be falling in love, once again, with SUVs. The Jeep Cherokee (NASDAQ:CHKE) had a great year.

So, talk to me about that and what those gas prices may mean for more fuel efficient cars like the hybrids.

LEBEAU: Well, something like the Toyota (NYSE:TM) Prius is a perfect example. We're going to see lower sales for the Prius and for other hybrids, and we're already seeing that this year. It's tougher to convince people that they should pay a slight premium to buy more fuel efficient gas electric hybrid vehicle. It's certainly tough, Tyler, because people can sit there and say, well, why don't I buy a compact car, I won't have to pay $3,000 more?

However, we should point out that fuel efficiency is now part of what people look for when they're going into the showroom. So, it's not as if people have forgotten about what happened ten years ago when we fell in love with gas guzzler, they're still thinking about that, but we are tending to go back towards the SUVs.

MATHISEN: Do we know anything about the aluminum bodied F-150 truck and how it's doing, supposedly more fuel-efficient?

LEBEAU: It's expected to be more fuel-efficient. We won't know how the public reacts to that new truck until well into next year. We're just seeing them trickle into showrooms. The early reviews are very positive. But that's usually with all new vehicles.

Talk to me in the middle of next year and we'll see how the public embraces it.

MATHISEN: All right. We'll get back to you, Phil. Thanks very much. Philip LeBeau in Chicago.

LEBEAU: You bet.

MATHISEN: Now to the hottest industry for mergers and acquisitions. This year, health care, a changing landscape and efforts to avoid U.S. corporate taxes through so-called inversion deals, made for a very busy year for some of the biggest drug makers?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN (voice-over): Pfizer (NYSE:PFE), Novartis, GlaxoSmithKline, Eli Lilly (NYSE:LLY), the biggest names in big pharma, all the subjects of deal talk, big deals, with tens of billions of dollars this year.

One reason: pressure on their product pipeline. It had some looking for growth outside their own company. Another reason? Taxes. Companies that could relocate to overseas addresses often get a tax break. The Washington did begin to clamp down on the so-called inversion craze with new rules in September.

The biggest of the pharma deals involve the Botox maker, Allergan (NYSE:AGN). The hedge funder Bill Ackman engineered an offer worth more than $50 billion for the company, but Allergan (NYSE:AGN) steered away and this fall, Allergan (NYSE:AGN) accepted an offer to join with Ireland's Actavis for $66 billion.

And that wasn't all for Actavis, which already made a deal back in July to buy another American company, Forest Labs for $28 billion.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And coming up, the Chinese e-commerce company that made its way to the New York Stock Exchange and became the biggest initial public offering ever.

(MUSIC)

MATHISEN: Perhaps the biggest stock story of the year with Alibaba's initial public offering. Not only did it introduce investors to its CEO Jack Ma, colorful guy, but it also claimed the title biggest IPO ever.

Kayla Tausche was at the New York Stock Exchange on the very day it started trading.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KAYLA TAUSCHE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Alibaba is off and running. The Chinese ecommerce giant soaring above $90 in its debut after pricing for $68 a share.

The company founded in the apartment of entrepreneur Jack Ma in 1999 with just a dozen partners now responsible for 80 percent of China's ecommerce and valued today by the public market in the United States at $240 billion.

Alibaba's business model is often described as a mash up between Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and eBay (NASDAQ:EBAY), but it's now is a formidable challenge to tech companies here in the U.S. It's bigger than Disney (NYSE:DIS), IBM and JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase.

But Ma said he draws inspiration from another U.S. corporation.

JACK MA, ALIBABA FOUNDER: We hope in the next 50 years, the world change because of that. We want to be bigger than Walmart. We want to be bigger -- it's not just the size, we want to learn from Walmart. They changed the business last century. They stressed the B2C.

And we hope, 15 years later, they say, this is a company like a Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT), like IBM, like Walmart. They changed and shaped the world.

TAUSCHE (on camera): Alibaba's platform sold $259 billion in goods last year and its vendors were responsible for 60 percent of all packages shipped in China. Alibaba helped small businesses connect to new customers and in turn buttressing China's middle class.

(voice-over): That's the main reason why investors have been clamoring for shares. They're willing to pay much more than the $68 IPO price set by the company, formally minting Hangzhou's Jack Ma as the richest man in mainland China.

But his fight to grow Alibaba is still centered on the little guy, when he's often reminded of by a famous movie character.

MA: The hero I had was Forrest Gump. And I watched the movie before I came here again, before -- for coming to New York, because I watched the movie again, telling me that no matter, whatever changed, you are you. And I'm still the guy 15 years ago.

TAUSCHE: Alibaba, of course, is now far bigger.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: And Kayla Tausche with us now for more on Alibaba and the other big tech stories of the year.

You know, Alibaba, the IPO, biggest ever, came off seemingly without a hitch. How did it change the landscape and the willingness for people to back these big IPOs?

TAUSCHE: You know, people were a little bit hesitant to see a company that was technically based in the Cayman Islands, with the bulk of its business in China, now trading here on U.S. soil. But investors really bought the story. They clamored to get the shares.

And when I talk to bankers on the day of the IPO, they said twice as many orders for shares of Alibaba coming from U.S. retail investors than they were for shares of Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Tyler. This has become a household name and it's really broken down the borders of ecommerce, this company that really was an upstart, came from nowhere, and all of the sudden, is bigger --

MATHISEN: Household name in China, but is it ever going to be a household name and a big player in the U.S.? What do you think?

TAUSCHE: The expectation is that it will and the demand from U.S. investors through their retail financial advisors trying to get these shares just shows you that it is starting to pick up a little bit. Now, it's bigger than JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) Chase. It's bigger than Facebook (NASDAQ:FB).

MATHISEN: What?

TAUSCHE: When you think about that market cap, Jack Ma was just saying in that piece, he wants to be bigger than Walmart. Well, his stock already is.

MATHISEN: All right. Now, explain to me the other one that maybe on the radar screen for 2015, and that is Uber, the ride-sharing service. The valuations that are being tossed around for this company, if it does indeed go public this year, are astronomical for what I think is a taxi service. I don't get it.

TAUSCHE: Well, the key to something like Uber and the reason why now is the time that a company like Uber can grow so much is this little tool right here, this smartphone. This wouldn't have been the power behind a company like Uber were we talking about five years ago.

But Uber is now worth $40 billion. Just six months ago, it was worth $18 billion, which even then sounded like an astounding number. A year and a half, worth $3.5 billion but investors say the earnings back that up that Uber in a year's time could make $10 billion in bookings because people say, hey, I don't want to get stuck in traffic. I'd like to have someone drive me and --

MATHISEN: Do you use it?

TAUSCHE: I do.

MATHISEN: I use it too.

TAUSCHE: And if the cost is comparable to a taxi, why not?

MATHISEN: All right. Kayla, thanks very much. Have a good New Year. All right. Thanks, everybody, for watching this special holiday edition of NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT. I'm Tyler Mathisen. Have a great evening, everybody. And we'll hope to see you right back here tomorrow night.

END
