ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Sue Herera.

TYLER MATHISEN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Seeking safety. Money flees stocks and floods the bond market on concerns over the health of the global economy. Is the U.S. strong enough to withstand weakness overseas?

SUE HERERA, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Retail route. Many thought consumers would spend all that money that they've been saving from cheap gas. But, today, we found out they didn't.

MATHISEN: And the Houston of Canada. How the dropping crude is sending a chill across the heart of Canada's energy industry.

All that and more tonight on NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Wednesday, January 14th.

HERERA: Good evening, everyone.

Another rough and unpredictable day on Wall Street with the major averages falling for the fourth straight session amid concerns about the strength of the U.S. consumer and the U.S. economy.

The big driver for today's selloff: retail sales falling nearly one percent in December, despite deep discounts, lower gas prices and a robust labor market. That, combined with more volatility and oil prices and a lower forecast for global economic growth, it sent stocks on another wild ride. The Dow cut an early 350 point loss in half, ending the session down 186 points, the NASDAQ lower by 22, and the S&P was down 11 points.

In the bond market, the yield on 30-year treasuries hit record lows while the yield on the benchmark ten-year note hit the lowest level in nearly two years.

Crude bounced between losses and gains spiking higher into the close, up 5.5 percent to $48.48 a barrel, its biggest one day percent gain since June of 2012.

So, with gas prices down and retail sales falling, what is the state of the U.S. consumer right now?

Steve Liesman takes a look.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Plunging oil prices have raised a few economic puzzles. First, since the U.S. is now such a huge oil producers, wouldn't it be a drag on the economy or a benefit? Second, and this is key to the first, what will consumers do with the windfall? Save it, spend it, or pay down debt?

Disappointing retail sales in December suggest consumers parting only reluctantly with those extra petro dollars in their pocket.

LIZ DUNN, TALMAGE ADVISORS FOUNDER & CEO: The consumer is cautious and waiting to see if this gas price thing is real, and I think they take a while before they adjust their spending pattern.

LIESMAN: To be sure, the case is not closed. Consumer spending was strong in October and November, leaving some economists to forecast the fourth quarter growth will sport the best consumer spending number since the Great Recession ended. The December data may yet be revised and just because consumers took a break doesn't mean the windfall won't find its way into more cash registers in January and beyond.

MICHELLE MEYER, BOFA MERRILL LYNCH GLOBAL RESEARCH: I think it's a blip in an otherwise strong trend for the consumer because look at the consumer backdrop. Healthy job growth, increase in disposable income, savings from the dropping gasoline prices, lower interest rates, wealth appreciation and consumer sentiment is improving.

LIESMAN (on camera): Now, let's go back to the first question. Is the plunge in oil good or bad for the U.S. economy? Right now, stock markets see only the negative -- plunging oil profits and oil stock prices. Soon enough, capital spending could take a hit as producers scale back on drilling new wells. And then, there's the uncertainty. Are oil prices down because demand and growth are weak worldwide?

(voice-over): Now, it's clear why the consumer is so key. Spending should be the opposite of the petro pessimism. But so far, it's not. The rule of thumb is that every $10 a barrel decline in oil means an extra quarter point to growth.

But right now, the rule is being challenged, as are the optimists who see lower oil prices as a positive for the U.S. economy but are still waiting for proof.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Steve Liesman.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: We are two weeks away now from the Federal Reserve's first policy setting meeting of the New Year. And today, the Fed is out with its latest Beige Book survey of economic conditions around the nation, a page turner. Businesses report modest to moderate growth across all 12 central bank regions helped by strong auto sales, a pickup in tourism and increased manufacturing. But that big drop in oil prices starting to impact Texas, says the Fed, and the other energy-producing regions.

HERERA: Another factor weighing on the markets today, global growth concerns. Here to talk about this and what means for investors is John Canally. He's the chief economist strategist at LPL Financial.

Welcome, John. Nice to have you here.

JOHN CANALLY, LPL FINANCIAL, CHIEF ECONOMIC STRATEGIST: Good to be here.

HERERA: Tell me what this market is telling you about global growth, or perhaps the lack of it. There's a lot of fear of deflation out there lately.

CANALLY: Yes, there is. And the ECB is working on that. They got that ruling today from the European court of justice that will allow them to do this sovereign quantitative easing next Thursday. So, that's a plus for global growth, but there's other concerns as well. Will the quantitative easing that Japan has been doing for the last year, will that start the work? Will China finally come out and say that they aren't going to grow at 7 percent next year, they're going to go at 6 1/2 percent, but will they do some other kind of fiscal and monetary stimulus on top of that?

And then taking it back to the U.S. here, the weak retail sales data this morning, kind of was the clincher and said, man, if the U.S. consumer isn't growing, then the U.S. isn't growing, then maybe we do have a global growth scare.

So, I think all that weighed on the market early. But as you mentioned, later in the day, the Beige Book came around, which is a much larger view of the U.S. economy, and that pretty much said things were OK, not great, but we're still sort of in a muddle through phase here as we wait for big events to unfold -- the ECB, China, things like that.

MATHISEN: John, we spend a tremendous time asking our guests, how low oil go? Tonight, the question tonight, how low will bond yields go? The 30-year bond yield now, at the lowest on record. Ten years at 1.8 percent or thereabouts.

What are they saying? What is the danger signal here, if any? And what should investors do if they own bonds?

CANALLY: Yes, that's the thing. I mean, is the bond market sending a signal because yields are at all time lows? I think if you were getting other signals from the economy, and consumer confidence was falling sharply instead of rising. If auto sales were at a 10-year low instead of a 10- year high, that would be a concern.

If you've seen things like retail sales, the weekly retail sales we get, if we get that and that was weak, that would be a signal that the bond market is telling us something. What we're seeing though is the opposite.

It's sort of the opposite of what happened in 2008. In 2008, we saw a big drop in bond yields and it was a global growth signal. Today, it's probably a signal of global deflation, disinflation rather than global growth. And I think there's things that are going to help that, but it may be a couple of weeks, a couple of months before markets are convinced that it's going to work.

HERERA: So, John, what I think I hear you saying is that the U.S. is the strongest around the globe right now, but is it strong enough to survive a global either disinflation or deflationary cycle?

CANALLY: Yes, I think it's important to remember that U.S. GDP is not S&P. So, S&P 500 profit is about 30 to 40 percent of those profits are derived from overseas. So, the stock market, financial markets are going to get a lot more volatile around the global growth scare.

The U.S. economy, maybe 10 percent to 15 percent relying on exports, but the other 85 percent to 95 percent is really just U.S. growth. And that looks fine. And, you know, as we've been saying that the U.S. is sort of the cleanest shirt in the hamper, or the best house on a bad street.

And as people look around the globe, they ask themselves where they want to be this year in terms of investing. Most likely it is in the U.S. until China can show its cards until the ECB can do what it does and until the Japan can do more.

So, I think from that perspective, I think the U.S. will be fine, simply because U.S. S&P 500 is a lot different than the make-up of our economy.

HERERA: The make-up.

All right, John. Thank you so much for that. We appreciate it. Chief economist at LPL Financial.

And more now on the impact of plunging energy costs. U.S. import prices saw their biggest drop in six years in December, tumbling 2.5 percent. That is the sixth month in a row of declines in import prices, keeping inflation in check.

MATHISEN: More detail now from that Beige Book survey out today, regarding the slide in oil prices. The Fed says the recent plunge in crude may be hurting economic growth as some U.S. energy companies are already reporting layoffs and spending freezes.

HERERA: And tumbling oil prices is having a big impact north of the border, where crude production is a driving force behind the Canadian economy.

Brian Sullivan has more from Calgary.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRIAN SULLIVAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Here in Canada, oil's price collapse is front page news. And while consumers love the drop in the price of gas lane, the oil producers and the government do not. Rapidly falling oil prices are going to hit everything from government budgets, to infrastructure building, to the Canadian dollar and jobs.

Massive Canadian oil company Sun Corp just announced it will be laying off 1,000 workers, and cutting a billion dollars from its capital spending plan. The potential downside is great enough that high ranking government officials are speaking out about it.

JIM PRENTICE, ALBERTA PREMIER: Oil prices continue to slip. We don't evidently -- haven't evidently seen the bottom yet, and this is opened up an enormous revenue shortfall in terms of the Alberta government's budget. Quantified for next year, $6 billion to $7 billion, $5 billion the year after that and $5 billion the year after if we don't take action.

SULLIVAN: Though finding an answer to the growing crisis is complex, the cause of the problem is not. The world is simply producing more oil than it is using. So, as supply and demand so out of whack, we asked an oil economist, why don't the big oil producers simply cut back on production?

PETER TERTZAKIAN, ARC FINANCIAL CORP: When you got a price for, all try to offset by producing more. So, it's a free for all for the moment. But, you know, until we see the participants in the global thing start to die off, we're going to see low prices.

SULLIVAN: Canada's oil pain is not just a Canada story. The stocks in more than 70 major Canadian companies trade in the United States. A number of those are oil companies and they have been walloped. Shares of Baytex Energy, Penn West Petroleum, Enerplus and Precision Drilling (NYSE:PDS) have seen their shares fall by more than 50 percent or even 60 percent in just a matter of months.

(on camera): Some call Calgary the "Houston of Canada" because of its strong job market and fast growth. But much of that is tied to the price of oil. And if oil's price were to fall lower, or even stay at this level for a long period of time, the building boom that you can clearly see behind us may simply run out of gas.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Brian Sullivan in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: And still ahead, scaling back. What the Republican- controlled House did today to two measures important to business.

(MUSIC)

HERERA: It was not a good day at J.P. Morgan Chase. The nation's biggest bank reported a 7 percent drop in earnings last quarter, getting slammed by a billion dollars in legal costs and a decline in trading revenue. Shares fell 3 1/2 percent today, weighing heavily on the entire financial sector.

MATHISEN: Things were a little bit better at Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC), the nation's biggest mortgage lender. Net income rose more than $5 billion, thanks to higher revenue from loan interest payments.

But chief financial officer John Shrewsberry says that growth is not just from home loans.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN SHREWSBERRY, WELLS FARGO CFO: Loan growth for Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) in the fourth quarter annualized, third to fourth quarter, grew at 13 percent, which is as strong as it's been in some time. So, some of that is mortgage, some is autos, it's in credit cards, it's all categories of commercial and industrial lending.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN: Despite that like a lot of other financials today, shares of Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) closed lower. They were down more than 1 percent.

HERERA: Mortgage applications took a big leap last week, the biggest weekly jump, in fact, in six years -- thanks to near-record low interest rates.

Diana Olick has the story from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DIANA OLICK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Mortgage applications spiked 49 percent last week and that was with the adjustment for the New Year's holiday. A sharp drop in interest rates, combined with new reduced cost for FHC and Fannie Mae loans were behind the move. Break it out, refis were a big driver, a 66 percent week-to-week to the highest level since July of 2013. Jumbo refis quadrupled, of course, they're more sensitive to interest rates.

Applications for a loan to purchase a home, up 24 percent from the previous week. They're also up 2 percent from a year ago, and that's the first time in over a year that they've been higher annually.

All this as the average contract rate on the 30-year fix conforming loan dropped to 3.89 percent. That is the lowest level since May of 2013.

Adding to the momentum, Fannie Mae's new 3 percent down payment loan and an announcement last week by FHA that it would cut annual insurance premiums by half a percent. That doesn't go into effect for a few weeks, but borrowers are applying, and FHA is actually allowing borrowers who are in process with the loan to cancel it and reapply under the new insurance rates.

Lenders tell me that is huge. One lender in northern Virginia calls the response unbelievable. He says people who have been debating buying a home are now going ahead with pre-qualifications in the hopes they'll find the house while rates are still low. It all bodes well for the spring housing market with one caveat. More people may want to buy homes at the new rate but there are still two few homes for sale. It's a vicious circle because people don't want to list their homes if they can't find something else to buy.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Diana Olick in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Moving to Washington now where the new Republican-led Congress is trying to reverse President Obama's immigration policies and roll back legislation regulating Wall Street banks.

John Harwood joins us now from Washington with more.

John, let's start with the efforts to roll back or postpone, I guess, some of the provisions of the Dodd-Frank law. What does today's House vote try to do here?

JOHN HARWOOD, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, what they're trying to do is delay by two years the imposition of the Volcker Rule. Now, remember, this is something that wasn't originally in the Dodd- Frank bill. So, this was added during the legislative process. You could have members of the financial community arguing that this was marginal to the importance of Dodd-Frank and Republicans agree with that argument. They're trying to roll it back.

The administration has drawn a line and said, no, they accepted some weakening of Dodd-Frank in legislation at the end of 2014, but they put a veto threat on this bill. Elizabeth Warren and Democratic liberals are mobilizing against it.

So, it's future in the Republican-led Senate where Democrats have a little more power because the power of the minority is very much in doubt.

HERERA: Yes, it sounds like it's almost DOA. I mean, is that a correct read? Or is there some hope?

HARWOOD: Well, there's a whole lot, as you know, of lobbying going on by Wall Street to try to target various portions of Dodd-Frank. We don't know where all of those efforts are going to lead. I would say that, as a stand-alone at this moment, it looks bleak but you could have back and forth as other various pieces of legislation, including tax reform get debated.

MATHISEN: All right. So, now, let's move on to the other key vote here. The House vote that ties the funding of the Homeland Security Department to undoing elements of the president's late last year executive order on immigration.

Does this have any chance of passing in the Senate most especially?

HARWOOD: More definitively, I would say it does not. Harry Reid, in fact, the Senate Democrat leader, put out a statement after the House passed this bill saying, you might as well forget it. This has no chance of clearing the Senate of the United States.

In both of these cases, by the way, you had defection of significance size within each party. You had on the Dodd-Frank legislation, 29 Democrats joined Republicans to say, yes, we should put off the Volcker Rule; 26 Republicans joined with Democrats to say, no, don't stop the president on immigration.

MATHISEN: All right, thanks very much, John. John Harwood reporting tonight from Washington.

HERERA: Takeover talks sent BlackBerry spiking right before the closing bell and that's where we begin tonight's "Market Focus".

Reuters is reporting that Samsung recently approached Blackberry about a potential takeover. It proposed an initial price range of between $13 and $15.50 a share for the smartphone maker. After the bell, Blackberry responded saying it has not engaged in those reported discussions. As you can see, Blackberry surged, closing about 30 percent to $12.60, but then shares fell slightly after hours. Samsung trades in Korea.

General Motors' 2015 financial outlook sent shares lower. The automaker expects to hike its capital expenditures by 20 percent this year as it looks to grow its luxury brand. But investors were disappointed when the company's CFO said that there are no plans for a dividend hike. Shares fell almost 3 percent to $34.40.

And one stock that participated in today's sell-off was Freeport McMoRan. The mining company was impacted by copper prices falling to a 5- year low. Copper is a major part of the company's business. Shares plunged about 11 percent to $18.74.

MATHISEN: Tough day for shares of Foot Locker, too. Goldman Sachs (NYSE:GS) downgraded the stock to "sell" from "neutral" and lowered its price target by $8. It cited concerns that peak margins on basketball sneakers may be a little risky. Shares slumped 4 percent today to $53.21. Its rival Finish Line fell, as we like to say, in sympathy about that.

A unit of Caesars Entertainment will file for bankruptcy tomorrow in Chicago, this according to a court filing. A group of the casino operator's bondholders have filed the papers to force the division into involuntary Chapter 11. Caesars has been trying to gain creditor's support for a restructuring program. Shares were up a fraction today to $12.71.

And Chipotle has pulled pork of its menu at a third of its locations. This after the company found out that one of its suppliers was not complying with its animal treatment standards. One supplier says it will pick up the slack to help address the shortfall, but investors were concerned after one analyst said the issue could impact the restaurants' first-quarter results. And shares were down today to $709.74, down $4.

Adobe saw its shares spike right after the close. This as the software company announced a new $2 billion stock buyback program. The new purchase plan will extend through 2017. And shares rose initially after hours. Before the close, though, the stock was down slightly to $69.99.

And coming up, the industry that's getting the attention of venture capitalists out in Silicon Valley and raking in record money.

(MUSIC)

HERERA: If you're expecting to get a tax refund this year, be prepared to wait a little longer to get it. Because of budget cuts, the IRS says that people who file paper tax returns may have to wait an extra week or longer to get that refund. The commissioner also said the IRS has met any returns with errors will also face delays and fewer calls to the help line will go unanswered.

On the other hand, those budget cuts may mean fewer audits as well.

MATHISEN: Etsy is going public and planning to raise $300 million. The Brooklyn-based seller of handmade crafts and hipster clothing -- this is so not me -- a reportedly plans to have an initial public offering as soon as this quarter.

HERERA: Well, Ty, if vintage clothing and crafts are not your thing, another place you may consider putting your money right now is health care start-ups, which were attracting a lot of interest from some big tech investors.

Josh Lipton has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOSH LIPTON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Talked to venture capitalists in Silicon Valley and asked them which industry they're most excited to revolutionize.

Odds are high that they'll say health care. So, it's no surprise that money is surging into start-ups that focus on that intersection of health care and technology. In 2014, venture funding for these start-ups hit a record $4.1 billion. That was a 125 percent year over year jump according to Rock Health, which provides seed funding for startups. Those working in this sector say health care is undergoing a technology transformation, with a range of startup aiming to make the industry more efficient, convenient, and cost-effective.

One such start-up is Omada Health, which connects those at risk for chronic diseases like diabetes to a comprehensive lifestyle program that includes a personal health coach and digital support group. The company's CEO says start-ups like his are attracting attention and money in part because there's now a new generation of entrepreneurs who are passionate about both health care and tech.

SEAN DUFFY, OMADA HEALTH CEO: I worked at Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) before going to medical school. Like I love -- I'm a huge techie. I love technology. I love health care.

And, you know, you have entrepreneurs that are now able to combine both and, you know, I think the venture capital investing community sees the chance for the next wave of folks that really, you know, take health care to a digital era.

LIPTON: So, which start-ups in the space are most likely to go public this year? They're tracking the space, including Fitbit, the maker of fitness trackers, ZocDoc, which allows users to all 50 states to find and book appointments for doctors online, Practice Fusion, a Cloud-based electronic health records provider, Proteus, which makes injectable sensors, and 23andMe, which provides genetic reports on your ancestry and family history.

One note of caution for investors, though, five digital health companies went public in 2014 according to Rock Health, raising a total of $1.7 billion. But three of those five stocks are now selling at below their offering price. And enthusiasm for this sector could cool if that trend continues this year.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Josh Lipton in Silicon Valley.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: A recap now of another volatile and losing session on Wall Street, and worries about the strength of the U.S. consumer and economic growth globally. The Dow off 186 points, half the losses from early in the trading day. NASDAQ was lower by 22. The S&P down 11. Oil, a sharp jump near the close, up 5.5 percent.

Dominic Chu is with us now.

Should we expect more of this, for example, tomorrow?

DOMINIC CHU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: You know, it's interesting because we've become so accustom to not seeing these kinds of swings.

MATHISEN: Yes.

CHU: You forget that this kind of thing can happen from time to time. Over the course of the past, the Q.E. era, we'll call it, the Fed's involvement in our markets -- we haven't seen a huge amount of volatility for the move.

Tomorrow, it's going to be very interesting because you've got a number of macro and micro, bigger picture economic things to consider, as well as company specific details.

On the macro front, you've got to worry about what's happening with the manufacturing picture overall. So, you've got the Philly Fed, Philadelphia area manufacturing and the economy, also the Empire State, that's New York.

Also, inflation data -- the producer price index comes up. That's going to be the macro picture.

On the micro front, tech and financial, the two most heavily weighted sectors in the entire S&P are going to be well-represented in earnings tomorrow. You've got the likes of Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) and Citi on the financial side. And then after the bell, you have Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), one of the biggest chip producers in the world.

All of those are going to give you a picture of what's going to happen with corporate America amidst this backdrop of volatility.

HERERA: I will be interested to see whether intel talks about currency and the impact of the stronger dollar on its earnings.

CHU: I would be surprised if any large cap company with international exposure does not talk about the strength of the dollar in terms of their earnings report. That's going to be a real key.

MATHISEN: And as you say, volatility is back. 2014, very low. 2015, so far, everyday has been a 100 point-day --

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: -- with some moves end up and down. But all of them had 100 points in them somewhere for the Dow.

CHU: You know, it's interesting. There's a lot of experts say that this is one of those times you're going to have to deal with that kind of volatility. Maybe not run for the exits, but still, buckle your safety belts.

HERERA: All right.

MATHISEN: Dom, thank you very much.

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: Dominic Chu.

HERERA: And that will do it for NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for tonight. I'm Sue Herera. Thanks for joining us.

MATHISEN: And I'm Tyler Mathisen. Have a great evening, everybody. And we will hope to see you right back here tomorrow night.

END

ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Sue Herera.

TYLER MATHISEN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Seeking safety. Money flees stocks and floods the bond market on concerns over the health of the global economy. Is the U.S. strong enough to withstand weakness overseas?

SUE HERERA, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Retail route. Many thought consumers would spend all that money that they've been saving from cheap gas. But, today, we found out they didn't.

MATHISEN: And the Houston of Canada. How the dropping crude is sending a chill across the heart of Canada's energy industry.

All that and more tonight on NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Wednesday, January 14th.

HERERA: Good evening, everyone.

Another rough and unpredictable day on Wall Street with the major averages falling for the fourth straight session amid concerns about the strength of the U.S. consumer and the U.S. economy.

The big driver for today's selloff: retail sales falling nearly one percent in December, despite deep discounts, lower gas prices and a robust labor market. That, combined with more volatility and oil prices and a lower forecast for global economic growth, it sent stocks on another wild ride. The Dow cut an early 350 point loss in half, ending the session down 186 points, the NASDAQ lower by 22, and the S&P was down 11 points.

In the bond market, the yield on 30-year treasuries hit record lows while the yield on the benchmark ten-year note hit the lowest level in nearly two years.

Crude bounced between losses and gains spiking higher into the close, up 5.5 percent to $48.48 a barrel, its biggest one day percent gain since June of 2012.

So, with gas prices down and retail sales falling, what is the state of the U.S. consumer right now?

Steve Liesman takes a look.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Plunging oil prices have raised a few economic puzzles. First, since the U.S. is now such a huge oil producers, wouldn't it be a drag on the economy or a benefit? Second, and this is key to the first, what will consumers do with the windfall? Save it, spend it, or pay down debt?

Disappointing retail sales in December suggest consumers parting only reluctantly with those extra petro dollars in their pocket.

LIZ DUNN, TALMAGE ADVISORS FOUNDER & CEO: The consumer is cautious and waiting to see if this gas price thing is real, and I think they take a while before they adjust their spending pattern.

LIESMAN: To be sure, the case is not closed. Consumer spending was strong in October and November, leaving some economists to forecast the fourth quarter growth will sport the best consumer spending number since the Great Recession ended. The December data may yet be revised and just because consumers took a break doesn't mean the windfall won't find its way into more cash registers in January and beyond.

MICHELLE MEYER, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH GLOBAL RESEARCH: I think it's a blip in an otherwise strong trend for the consumer because look at the consumer backdrop. Healthy job growth, increase in disposable income, savings from the dropping gasoline prices, lower interest rates, wealth appreciation and consumer sentiment is improving.

LIESMAN (on camera): Now, let's go back to the first question. Is the plunge in oil good or bad for the U.S. economy? Right now, stock markets see only the negative -- plunging oil profits and oil stock prices. Soon enough, capital spending could take a hit as producers scale back on drilling new wells. And then, there's the uncertainty. Are oil prices down because demand and growth are weak worldwide?

(voice-over): Now, it's clear why the consumer is so key. Spending should be the opposite of the petro pessimism. But so far, it's not. The rule of thumb is that every $10 a barrel decline in oil means an extra quarter point to growth.

But right now, the rule is being challenged, as are the optimists who see lower oil prices as a positive for the U.S. economy but are still waiting for proof.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Steve Liesman.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: We are two weeks away now from the Federal Reserve's first policy setting meeting of the New Year. And today, the Fed is out with its latest Beige Book survey of economic conditions around the nation, a page turner. Businesses report modest to moderate growth across all 12 central bank regions helped by strong auto sales, a pickup in tourism and increased manufacturing. But that big drop in oil prices starting to impact Texas, says the Fed, and the other energy-producing regions.

HERERA: Another factor weighing on the markets today, global growth concerns. Here to talk about this and what means for investors is John Canally. He's the chief economist strategist at LPL Financial.

Welcome, John. Nice to have you here.

JOHN CANALLY, LPL FINANCIAL, CHIEF ECONOMIC STRATEGIST: Good to be here.

HERERA: Tell me what this market is telling you about global growth, or perhaps the lack of it. There's a lot of fear of deflation out there lately.

CANALLY: Yes, there is. And the ECB is working on that. They got that ruling today from the European court of justice that will allow them to do this sovereign quantitative easing next Thursday. So, that's a plus for global growth, but there's other concerns as well. Will the quantitative easing that Japan has been doing for the last year, will that start the work? Will China finally come out and say that they aren't going to grow at 7 percent next year, they're going to go at 6 1/2 percent, but will they do some other kind of fiscal and monetary stimulus on top of that?

And then taking it back to the U.S. here, the weak retail sales data this morning, kind of was the clincher and said, man, if the U.S. consumer isn't growing, then the U.S. isn't growing, then maybe we do have a global growth scare.

So, I think all that weighed on the market early. But as you mentioned, later in the day, the Beige Book came around, which is a much larger view of the U.S. economy, and that pretty much said things were OK, not great, but we're still sort of in a muddle through phase here as we wait for big events to unfold -- the ECB, China, things like that.

MATHISEN: John, we spend a tremendous time asking our guests, how low oil go? Tonight, the question tonight, how low will bond yields go? The 30-year bond yield now, at the lowest on record. Ten years at 1.8 percent or thereabouts.

What are they saying? What is the danger signal here, if any? And what should investors do if they own bonds?

CANALLY: Yes, that's the thing. I mean, is the bond market sending a signal because yields are at all time lows? I think if you were getting other signals from the economy, and consumer confidence was falling sharply instead of rising. If auto sales were at a 10-year low instead of a 10- year high, that would be a concern.

If you've seen things like retail sales, the weekly retail sales we get, if we get that and that was weak, that would be a signal that the bond market is telling us something. What we're seeing though is the opposite.

It's sort of the opposite of what happened in 2008. In 2008, we saw a big drop in bond yields and it was a global growth signal. Today, it's probably a signal of global deflation, disinflation rather than global growth. And I think there's things that are going to help that, but it may be a couple of weeks, a couple of months before markets are convinced that it's going to work.

HERERA: So, John, what I think I hear you saying is that the U.S. is the strongest around the globe right now, but is it strong enough to survive a global either disinflation or deflationary cycle?

CANALLY: Yes, I think it's important to remember that U.S. GDP is not S&P. So, S&P 500 profit is about 30 to 40 percent of those profits are derived from overseas. So, the stock market, financial markets are going to get a lot more volatile around the global growth scare.

The U.S. economy, maybe 10 percent to 15 percent relying on exports, but the other 85 percent to 95 percent is really just U.S. growth. And that looks fine. And, you know, as we've been saying that the U.S. is sort of the cleanest shirt in the hamper, or the best house on a bad street.

And as people look around the globe, they ask themselves where they want to be this year in terms of investing. Most likely it is in the U.S. until China can show its cards until the ECB can do what it does and until the Japan can do more.

So, I think from that perspective, I think the U.S. will be fine, simply because U.S. S&P 500 is a lot different than the make-up of our economy.

HERERA: The make-up.

All right, John. Thank you so much for that. We appreciate it. Chief economist at LPL Financial.

And more now on the impact of plunging energy costs. U.S. import prices saw their biggest drop in six years in December, tumbling 2.5 percent. That is the sixth month in a row of declines in import prices, keeping inflation in check.

MATHISEN: More detail now from that Beige Book survey out today, regarding the slide in oil prices. The Fed says the recent plunge in crude may be hurting economic growth as some U.S. energy companies are already reporting layoffs and spending freezes.

HERERA: And tumbling oil prices is having a big impact north of the border, where crude production is a driving force behind the Canadian economy.

Brian Sullivan has more from Calgary.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRIAN SULLIVAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Here in Canada, oil's price collapse is front page news. And while consumers love the drop in the price of gas lane, the oil producers and the government do not. Rapidly falling oil prices are going to hit everything from government budgets, to infrastructure building, to the Canadian dollar and jobs.

Massive Canadian oil company Sun Corp just announced it will be laying off 1,000 workers, and cutting a billion dollars from its capital spending plan. The potential downside is great enough that high ranking government officials are speaking out about it.

JIM PRENTICE, ALBERTA PREMIER: Oil prices continue to slip. We don't evidently -- haven't evidently seen the bottom yet, and this is opened up an enormous revenue shortfall in terms of the Alberta government's budget. Quantified for next year, $6 billion to $7 billion, $5 billion the year after that and $5 billion the year after if we don't take action.

SULLIVAN: Though finding an answer to the growing crisis is complex, the cause of the problem is not. The world is simply producing more oil than it is using. So, as supply and demand so out of whack, we asked an oil economist, why don't the big oil producers simply cut back on production?

PETER TERTZAKIAN, ARC FINANCIAL CORP: When you got a price for, all try to offset by producing more. So, it's a free for all for the moment. But, you know, until we see the participants in the global thing start to die off, we're going to see low prices.

SULLIVAN: Canada's oil pain is not just a Canada story. The stocks in more than 70 major Canadian companies trade in the United States. A number of those are oil companies and they have been walloped. Shares of Baytex Energy, Penn West Petroleum, Enerplus and Precision Drilling (NYSE:PDS) have seen their shares fall by more than 50 percent or even 60 percent in just a matter of months.

(on camera): Some call Calgary the "Houston of Canada" because of its strong job market and fast growth. But much of that is tied to the price of oil. And if oil's price were to fall lower, or even stay at this level for a long period of time, the building boom that you can clearly see behind us may simply run out of gas.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Brian Sullivan in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: And still ahead, scaling back. What the Republican- controlled House did today to two measures important to business.

(MUSIC)

HERERA: It was not a good day at J.P. Morgan Chase. The nation's biggest bank reported a 7 percent drop in earnings last quarter, getting slammed by a billion dollars in legal costs and a decline in trading revenue. Shares fell 3 1/2 percent today, weighing heavily on the entire financial sector.

MATHISEN: Things were a little bit better at Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC), the nation's biggest mortgage lender. Net income rose more than $5 billion, thanks to higher revenue from loan interest payments.

But chief financial officer John Shrewsberry says that growth is not just from home loans.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN SHREWSBERRY, WELLS FARGO CFO: Loan growth for Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) in the fourth quarter annualized, third to fourth quarter, grew at 13 percent, which is as strong as it's been in some time. So, some of that is mortgage, some is autos, it's in credit cards, it's all categories of commercial and industrial lending.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATHISEN: Despite that like a lot of other financials today, shares of Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) closed lower. They were down more than 1 percent.

HERERA: Mortgage applications took a big leap last week, the biggest weekly jump, in fact, in six years -- thanks to near-record low interest rates.

Diana Olick has the story from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DIANA OLICK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Mortgage applications spiked 49 percent last week and that was with the adjustment for the New Year's holiday. A sharp drop in interest rates, combined with new reduced cost for FHC and Fannie Mae loans were behind the move. Break it out, refis were a big driver, a 66 percent week-to-week to the highest level since July of 2013. Jumbo refis quadrupled, of course, they're more sensitive to interest rates.

Applications for a loan to purchase a home, up 24 percent from the previous week. They're also up 2 percent from a year ago, and that's the first time in over a year that they've been higher annually.

All this as the average contract rate on the 30-year fix conforming loan dropped to 3.89 percent. That is the lowest level since May of 2013.

Adding to the momentum, Fannie Mae's new 3 percent down payment loan and an announcement last week by FHA that it would cut annual insurance premiums by half a percent. That doesn't go into effect for a few weeks, but borrowers are applying, and FHA is actually allowing borrowers who are in process with the loan to cancel it and reapply under the new insurance rates.

Lenders tell me that is huge. One lender in northern Virginia calls the response unbelievable. He says people who have been debating buying a home are now going ahead with pre-qualifications in the hopes they'll find the house while rates are still low. It all bodes well for the spring housing market with one caveat. More people may want to buy homes at the new rate but there are still two few homes for sale. It's a vicious circle because people don't want to list their homes if they can't find something else to buy.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Diana Olick in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: Moving to Washington now where the new Republican-led Congress is trying to reverse President Obama's immigration policies and roll back legislation regulating Wall Street banks.

John Harwood joins us now from Washington with more.

John, let's start with the efforts to roll back or postpone, I guess, some of the provisions of the Dodd-Frank law. What does today's House vote try to do here?

JOHN HARWOOD, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Well, what they're trying to do is delay by two years the imposition of the Volcker Rule. Now, remember, this is something that wasn't originally in the Dodd- Frank bill. So, this was added during the legislative process. You could have members of the financial community arguing that this was marginal to the importance of Dodd-Frank and Republicans agree with that argument. They're trying to roll it back.

The administration has drawn a line and said, no, they accepted some weakening of Dodd-Frank in legislation at the end of 2014, but they put a veto threat on this bill. Elizabeth Warren and Democratic liberals are mobilizing against it.

So, it's future in the Republican-led Senate where Democrats have a little more power because the power of the minority is very much in doubt.

HERERA: Yes, it sounds like it's almost DOA. I mean, is that a correct read? Or is there some hope?

HARWOOD: Well, there's a whole lot, as you know, of lobbying going on by Wall Street to try to target various portions of Dodd-Frank. We don't know where all of those efforts are going to lead. I would say that, as a stand-alone at this moment, it looks bleak but you could have back and forth as other various pieces of legislation, including tax reform get debated.

MATHISEN: All right. So, now, let's move on to the other key vote here. The House vote that ties the funding of the Homeland Security Department to undoing elements of the president's late last year executive order on immigration.

Does this have any chance of passing in the Senate most especially?

HARWOOD: More definitively, I would say it does not. Harry Reid, in fact, the Senate Democrat leader, put out a statement after the House passed this bill saying, you might as well forget it. This has no chance of clearing the Senate of the United States.

In both of these cases, by the way, you had defection of significance size within each party. You had on the Dodd-Frank legislation, 29 Democrats joined Republicans to say, yes, we should put off the Volcker Rule; 26 Republicans joined with Democrats to say, no, don't stop the president on immigration.

MATHISEN: All right, thanks very much, John. John Harwood reporting tonight from Washington.

HERERA: Takeover talks sent BlackBerry spiking right before the closing bell and that's where we begin tonight's "Market Focus".

Reuters is reporting that Samsung recently approached Blackberry about a potential takeover. It proposed an initial price range of between $13 and $15.50 a share for the smartphone maker. After the bell, Blackberry responded saying it has not engaged in those reported discussions. As you can see, Blackberry surged, closing about 30 percent to $12.60, but then shares fell slightly after hours. Samsung trades in Korea.

General Motors' 2015 financial outlook sent shares lower. The automaker expects to hike its capital expenditures by 20 percent this year as it looks to grow its luxury brand. But investors were disappointed when the company's CFO said that there are no plans for a dividend hike. Shares fell almost 3 percent to $34.40.

And one stock that participated in today's sell-off was Freeport McMoRan. The mining company was impacted by copper prices falling to a 5- year low. Copper is a major part of the company's business. Shares plunged about 11 percent to $18.74.

MATHISEN: Tough day for shares of Foot Locker, too. Goldman Sachs (NYSE:GS) downgraded the stock to "sell" from "neutral" and lowered its price target by $8. It cited concerns that peak margins on basketball sneakers may be a little risky. Shares slumped 4 percent today to $53.21. Its rival Finish Line fell, as we like to say, in sympathy about that.

A unit of Caesars Entertainment will file for bankruptcy tomorrow in Chicago, this according to a court filing. A group of the casino operator's bondholders have filed the papers to force the division into involuntary Chapter 11. Caesars has been trying to gain creditor's support for a restructuring program. Shares were up a fraction today to $12.71.

And Chipotle has pulled pork of its menu at a third of its locations. This after the company found out that one of its suppliers was not complying with its animal treatment standards. One supplier says it will pick up the slack to help address the shortfall, but investors were concerned after one analyst said the issue could impact the restaurants' first-quarter results. And shares were down today to $709.74, down $4.

Adobe saw its shares spike right after the close. This as the software company announced a new $2 billion stock buyback program. The new purchase plan will extend through 2017. And shares rose initially after hours. Before the close, though, the stock was down slightly to $69.99.

And coming up, the industry that's getting the attention of venture capitalists out in Silicon Valley and raking in record money.

(MUSIC)

HERERA: If you're expecting to get a tax refund this year, be prepared to wait a little longer to get it. Because of budget cuts, the IRS says that people who file paper tax returns may have to wait an extra week or longer to get that refund. The commissioner also said the IRS has met any returns with errors will also face delays and fewer calls to the help line will go unanswered.

On the other hand, those budget cuts may mean fewer audits as well.

MATHISEN: Etsy is going public and planning to raise $300 million. The Brooklyn-based seller of handmade crafts and hipster clothing -- this is so not me -- a reportedly plans to have an initial public offering as soon as this quarter.

HERERA: Well, Ty, if vintage clothing and crafts are not your thing, another place you may consider putting your money right now is health care start-ups, which were attracting a lot of interest from some big tech investors.

Josh Lipton has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOSH LIPTON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Talked to venture capitalists in Silicon Valley and asked them which industry they're most excited to revolutionize.

Odds are high that they'll say health care. So, it's no surprise that money is surging into start-ups that focus on that intersection of health care and technology. In 2014, venture funding for these start-ups hit a record $4.1 billion. That was a 125 percent year over year jump according to Rock Health, which provides seed funding for startups. Those working in this sector say health care is undergoing a technology transformation, with a range of startup aiming to make the industry more efficient, convenient, and cost-effective.

One such start-up is Omada Health, which connects those at risk for chronic diseases like diabetes to a comprehensive lifestyle program that includes a personal health coach and digital support group. The company's CEO says start-ups like his are attracting attention and money in part because there's now a new generation of entrepreneurs who are passionate about both health care and tech.

SEAN DUFFY, OMADA HEALTH CEO: I worked at Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) before going to medical school. Like I love -- I'm a huge techie. I love technology. I love health care.

And, you know, you have entrepreneurs that are now able to combine both and, you know, I think the venture capital investing community sees the chance for the next wave of folks that really, you know, take health care to a digital era.

LIPTON: So, which start-ups in the space are most likely to go public this year? They're tracking the space, including Fitbit, the maker of fitness trackers, ZocDoc, which allows users to all 50 states to find and book appointments for doctors online, Practice Fusion, a Cloud-based electronic health records provider, Proteus, which makes injectable sensors, and 23andMe, which provides genetic reports on your ancestry and family history.

One note of caution for investors, though, five digital health companies went public in 2014 according to Rock Health, raising a total of $1.7 billion. But three of those five stocks are now selling at below their offering price. And enthusiasm for this sector could cool if that trend continues this year.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Josh Lipton in Silicon Valley.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MATHISEN: A recap now of another volatile and losing session on Wall Street, and worries about the strength of the U.S. consumer and economic growth globally. The Dow off 186 points, half the losses from early in the trading day. NASDAQ was lower by 22. The S&P down 11. Oil, a sharp jump near the close, up 5.5 percent.

Dominic Chu is with us now.

Should we expect more of this, for example, tomorrow?

DOMINIC CHU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: You know, it's interesting because we've become so accustom to not seeing these kinds of swings.

MATHISEN: Yes.

CHU: You forget that this kind of thing can happen from time to time. Over the course of the past, the Q.E. era, we'll call it, the Fed's involvement in our markets -- we haven't seen a huge amount of volatility for the move.

Tomorrow, it's going to be very interesting because you've got a number of macro and micro, bigger picture economic things to consider, as well as company specific details.

On the macro front, you've got to worry about what's happening with the manufacturing picture overall. So, you've got the Philly Fed, Philadelphia area manufacturing and the economy, also the Empire State, that's New York.

Also, inflation data -- the producer price index comes up. That's going to be the macro picture.

On the micro front, tech and financial, the two most heavily weighted sectors in the entire S&P are going to be well-represented in earnings tomorrow. You've got the likes of Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) and Citi on the financial side. And then after the bell, you have Intel (NASDAQ:INTC), one of the biggest chip producers in the world.

All of those are going to give you a picture of what's going to happen with corporate America amidst this backdrop of volatility.

HERERA: I will be interested to see whether intel talks about currency and the impact of the stronger dollar on its earnings.

CHU: I would be surprised if any large cap company with international exposure does not talk about the strength of the dollar in terms of their earnings report. That's going to be a real key.

MATHISEN: And as you say, volatility is back. 2014, very low. 2015, so far, everyday has been a 100 point-day --

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: -- with some moves end up and down. But all of them had 100 points in them somewhere for the Dow.

CHU: You know, it's interesting. There's a lot of experts say that this is one of those times you're going to have to deal with that kind of volatility. Maybe not run for the exits, but still, buckle your safety belts.

HERERA: All right.

MATHISEN: Dom, thank you very much.

CHU: Sure.

MATHISEN: Dominic Chu.

HERERA: And that will do it for NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for tonight. I'm Sue Herera. Thanks for joining us.

MATHISEN: And I'm Tyler Mathisen. Have a great evening, everybody. And we will hope to see you right back here tomorrow night.

END
